Indicator ID: 9(a) Significantly reducing climate-induced water scarcity and enhancing climate resilience to water-related hazards towards a climate-resilient water supply, climate-resilient sanitation and access to safe and affordable potable water for all

Indicator name: Change in water stress levels over time
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By sector and geographical area and used in combination with indicators recording water-related adaptation measures taken disaggregated by sector and geographical area.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Significantly reducing climate-induced water scarcity
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures change in the level of water stress over time. It is calculated as the ratio between total freshwater withdrawn by all major sectors and total renewable freshwater resources, after taking into account environmental flow requirements. Main sectors, as defined by ISIC standards, include agriculture; forestry and fishing; manufacturing; electricity industry; and services. Data on water withdrawals and total water resources available are commonly collected by national line ministries and institutions (e.g. for Water, Agriculture and Environment) and the National Statistical Office and can be used to assess current status and trends over time.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This indicator is a measure of the sustainability of water withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity. Lower water stress directly reduces vulnerability and enhances community resilience, ensuring reliable water supplies for households, agriculture, and industry. Adaptation actions such as improved water management and conservation buffer the impacts of drought and variability, safeguarding livelihoods and ecosystems against climate-induced stress.

This indicator builds on the existing global indicator SDG 6.4.2, which is an established outcome indicator with existing guidance and system of reporting under SDG 6.4.2. Part of a Global set of Climate Change Statistics and Indicators adopted by UN Statistical Commission in 2022. Included in UNSD/UNEP/OECD/ Eurostat Questionnaire on Environment Statistics.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9b Food & agricultural, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: It could refer to the original SDG indicator 6.4.2 metadata: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/
Data availability\n(Description): For the original SDG indicator 6.4.2, 180 Parties have reported on the original indicator in the past 5 years.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Further development of methodology and reporting process on disaggration by geographical area (especially freshwater basin) and additional reporting of adaptation measures would be required.

Indicator name: Change in water-use efficiency over time
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Significantly reducing climate-induced water scarcity;
Towards a climate-resilient water supply
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The indicator tracks the value added in monetary value (e.g. US dollars) per volume of water used in cubic meters, by a given economic activity over time. It considers water use by all economic activities, with a focus on agriculture, industry and the service sector. Data on water use are commonly available from the records of national line ministries and institutions (e.g. for Water, Agriculture and Environment), and data on value generation in different sectors are commonly available from the National Statistical Office and can be used to assess current status and trends over time.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Increasing water-use efficiency reduces vulnerability to climate change by maximizing the benefits from existing water resources.

The modified indicator builds on the existing global indicator "SDG 6.4.1: Change in water-use efficiency over time", which is an established output indicator with existing guidance and system of reporting under SDG 6.4.1. Measured as the ratio of dollar value added to the volume of water used. Can be disaggregated by sector (agriculture, forestry and fishing, industry and services). Can be used to target sectors with high use and low efficiency. Data on water use comes from national line ministries and data on value generation from National Statistical Offices. Increasing water-use efficiency (repairing leaking water distribution systems, using less thirsty crops and investing in new technology) can result in more sustainable and resilient food and industrial production systems. Water savings are also associated with energy savings, as less water needs to be extracted, treated, transported and heated.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9b Food & agricultural, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10d MEL, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: It could refer to the original SDG indicator 6.4.1 metadata: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/
Data availability\n(Description): For the original SDG indicator 6.4.1, 168 Parties have reported on the orginal indicator in the past 5 years. Data on water use comes from national line ministries and data on value generation from National Statistical Offices. Further work required to determine data availability for Parties.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Existing SDG indicator, ready for adoption

Indicator name: Proportion of critical water and sanitation infrastructure systems that are built or retrofitted to withstand climate-related hazards
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Climate-related hazards, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Includes information disaggregated by individual basin (including transboundary basins) and by type of water bodies (e.g. rivers, lakes, aquifers)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Enhancing climate resilience to water-related hazards
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures proportion of critical water and sanitation infrastructure systems that are built or retrofitted to conform with national regulations and standards for climate resilience. Critical water infrastructure refers to essential water-related systems and facilities that have the ability to prevent, protect against, or recover from disasters. This ensures that services essential for the maintenance of vital societal functions, economic activities, public health and safety, or the environment (essential services) are constantly available. Critical water related infrastructure could include among others (and it is not limited to) drinking water suppliers and distributor networks, reservoirs, dams, wastewater collection and treatment plants, electricity production like hydropower, transport on water and flood protection systems, irrigation systems and supporting assets like pumps and control centers. Water and sanitation infrastructure may be considered critical for health, education, agriculture, industry or other purposes. Data on the number and proportion of critical water and sanitation infrastructure systems that are designed, built or retrofitted to withstand climate-related hazards is typically available from National Adaptation Plans, or equivalent policy instruments, and from relevant national line ministries and institutions (e.g. for Water, Agriculture and Environment).
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Critical infrastructure systems are essential for the functioning of societies and economies. Upgrading water infrastructure (water and sewage treatment plants, irrigation, hydropower and multipurpose dams, pipelines, drinking water infrastructure e.g reservoirs, pipelines, groundwater wells and mountain springs) strengthens the ability to withstand floods, droughts, and other climate related extreme events, reducing disruption and ensuring safe water access for drinking, sanitiation, agriculture, industry, energy and health under changing climate conditions.  These water and sanitation infrastructure systems ensure the continuous supply and quality of water, enable safe disposal of wastewater, support flood control, and are essential for ensuring public health and safety and sustaining economic activities. This is crucial for economic growth and productivity and protecting public health.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9c Health, 9b Food & agricultural, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata would need to be developed.
Data availability\n(Description): Data may be available for some Parties that reporting on project-level progress of the impenmentation of National Adaptation Plans, or equivalent policy instruments. However, such data would also need to be standardized and checked agained metadata, once developed. Calculating the proportion would also require data about the total critical water and sanitation infrastructure systems per country.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: Institutional arrangements, Strengthened and inclusive governance, Policies
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: First step would be to develop metadata and check data availability.

Indicator name: Proportion of total area of basins (river, lake or aquifer) and cryosphere (glacier, snow and ice) for which a climate adaptation plan is developed and implemented as part of an integrated water resources management approach
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Includes information disaggregated by individual basin (including transboundary basins) and by type of water bodies (e.g. rivers, lakes, aquifers)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Enhancing climate resilience to water-related hazards
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator builds on and combines two established process indicators – SDG 6.5.1 and SDG 6.5.2 – and includes climate risk assessment and adaptation planning and implementation across entire basins (wholly within a country or transboundary) as part of an integrated water resource management approach, and also extends to the cryosphere as an important source of freshwater resources. The goal is to eventually reach 100% of the total area of a basin (lake, river or aquifer) for which a climate risk assessment is conducted/updated and an adaptation plan developed and implemented under an integrated water resources management approach. Data on the number and proportion of basins (including transboundary basins) that have developed and implemented climate adaptation plans as part of an integrated water resources management approach are typically available from national line ministries and institutions (e.g. for Water, Agriculture and Environment).
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Regular climate risk assessment and adaptation planning for river basins, aquifers, and lakes, as well as the cryosphere (such as snow, glaciers, ice sheets, and permafrost), identify vulnerabilities and guide strategic interventions. Integrated water resources management ensures sustainable use, balancing water needs for people, environment, and economy under climate uncertainties. The modified indicator builds on and combines established process indicators with existing guidance and system of reporting under SDG 6.5.1 (water resources management) and 6.5.2 (transboundary cooperation). We recommend that disaggregated information is collected for individual river basins and lake basins and then aggregated for global reporting.

Specifically for the cryosphere, almost 70% of Earth’s freshwater is stored as snow or ice. Runoff from glaciers, snow and ice are essential for drinking water, agriculture, industry and clean energy production. Climate and cryosphere change impact the water cycle, including changing the amount and timing of glacier melt and snowmelt discharge, groundwater recharge and low flows, and contribute to sea level rise. Integrated water management approaches across multiple scales can be effective at addressing impacts and leveraging opportunities from cryosphere changes in high mountain areas (IPCC SROCC SPM C2.6).
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9b Food & agricultural, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10b Planning, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: It would refer to and build on the original SDG 6.5.1 and SDG 6.5.2 metadata: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/
Data availability\n(Description):
153 Parties share transboundary waters and cooperation is important for effective management of water-related hazards. 124 Parties have reported on the orginal indicator in the last 5 years. Further work required to determine data availability for Parties.

The WMO's Global Cryosphere Watch (GCW) fosters international coordination and partnerships between scientific and operational communities.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: Institutional arrangements, Policies, Strengthened and inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: It builds on the current data collection and reporting framework of two existing SDG indicators SDG 6.5.1 and SDG 6.5.2, so it would be relatively easy to operationalise

Indicator name: Proportion of population using drinking water services that are safely managed and climate resilient
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Towards a climate-resilient water supply;
Access to safe and affordable potable water for all
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator builds on the established SDG indicator 6.1.1 which tracks the proportion of the population using safely managed drinking water services (an improved drinking water source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free of faecal and priority chemical contamination) and integrates additional information on climate resilience. A standardized definition and methodology for assessing "climate resilient" drinking water services is currently being developed by the WHO/UNICEF JMP which is responsible for global monitoring of drinking water, sanitation and hygiene.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Access to climate-resilient water services ensures safe drinking water during and after floods, droughts, and other hazards. Ensuring coverage across diverse population groups guarantees public health and supports adaptation for all. Standardised indicators for monitoring accessibility, availability and quality of drinking water supplies are well established and available for the majority of Parties. Indicators of climate resilience are not yet standardized but typically combine information on adaptation actions by governments, service providers and users, physical attributes of water supply infrastructure, water service functioning and user experience of water services. We recommend that indicators for climate resilient drinking water services are standardized and integrated into national monitoring systems and disaggregated by climate-related hazard and by rural and urban, subnational region, wealth quintile and other relevant socio-economic characteristics to address inequalities between population subgroups.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9c Health, 9b Food & agricultural, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: It could refer to and build on the original SDG indicator 6.1.1 metadata: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/, however the definition and metadata of "climate resilient" drinking water services would need to be developed.
Data availability\n(Description): For the original SDG indicator 6.1.1, comparable estimates available for 142 Parties in 2022 (51% of global population). However, exact data availability needs to be checked once the modified metadata is developed. Further work required to determine data availability for Parties.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The first step would be to develop the definition and methodology for assessing "climate resilient" drinking water services, and then modify the existing SDG indicator 6.1.1 metadata accordingly.

Corresponding sub-target / component: Towards a climate-resilient sanitation
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator builds on the established SDG indicator 6.2.1a which tracks the proportion of the population using safely managed sanitation services (an improved sanitation facility that is not share with other households and where excreta are safely disposed of in situ or removed and treated off-site) and integrates additional information on climate resilience. A standardized definition and methodology for assessing "climate resilient" sanitation services is currently being developed by the WHO/UNICEF JMP which is responsible for global monitoring of drinking water, sanitation and hygiene.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Access to climate-resilient sanitation services ensures safe sanitation during and after floods, droughts, and other hazards. Ensuring coverage across diverse population groups guarantees public health and supports adaptation for all. Standardised indicators for monitoring accessibility, availability and quality of sanitation services are well established and available for the majority of Parties. Indicators of climate resilience are not yet standardized but typically combine information on adaptation actions by governments, service providers and users, physical attributes of sanitation infrastructure, sanitation service functioning and user experience of sanitation and services. We recommend that indicators for climate resilient sanitation services are standardized and integrated into national monitoring systems and disaggregated by climate-related hazard and rural and urban, subnational region, wealth quintile and other relevant socio-economic characteristics to address inequalities between population subgroups.

We recommend that indicators for climate resilient sanitation services are standardized and integrated into national monitoring systems and disaggregated by climate-related hazard and rural and urban, subnational region, wealth quintile and other relevant socio-economic characteristics to address inequalities between population subgroups.

Indicator name: Proportion of Parties taking measures to improve and extend WASH services to populations disproportionately affected by climate change and to vulnerable groups
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Access to safe and affordable potable water for all;
towards a climate resilient water supply; towards climate-resilient sanitation;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This builds on an established indicator which tracks the extent to which national policies and plans for drinking water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) include measures to improve and extend WASH services to populations disproportionately affected by climate change. The populations disproportionately affected by climate change vary by Party. Measures to improve and extend services include extending services to unserved populations, upgrading existing services, provision of alternative services, and measures to ensure affordability and equitable access to WASH services for all including vulnerable groups.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Targeted adaptation measures are required to address the uneven impact of climate change on drinking water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) service levels. Specific measures are required to protect and support those populations that are disproportionately impacted by climate change. Populations that remain unserved and those with the lowest levels of WASH service are typically most the most vulnerable. Populations relying on specific sources (rainwater, surface water, groundwater) or technologies (piped and non-piped systems) may be more vulnerable than others. In all cases poor and marginalized groups  
ASH address the needs of children, infants, pregnant women, and other vulnerable groups. Expanding services in affected areas reduces health risks and advances social equity.

The modified indicator builds on the existing UN-Water Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking-Water (GLAAS) indicator and added the emphasis on effects on vulnerable groups. It would be a potential input indicator for climate resilient water supply and climate resilient sanitation. Established system of reporting under UN Water GLAAS.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9c Health, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10c Implementation, 9f Poverty & livelihoods
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The existing metadata under UN Water Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking-Water (GLAAS) may need slight adjustment to ensure proper monitoring and reporting of measures targeted at vulnerable groups.
Data availability\n(Description): Baseline data of the original GLAAS indicator are available for ~100 Parties. However, the data availability on disaggration by vulnerable groups and by climate-related hazard would need to be checked. Further work required to determine data availability for Parties.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: First step would be to refine the metadata of the original indicator and check the current data collection to ensure the modified indicator can adquately report on targeted measures for vulnerable groups.

Indicator name: Proportion of bodies of water with good ambient water quality
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by water body (rivers, lakes and aquifers)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Access to safe and affordable potable water for all
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This builds on an established indicator which tracks the extent to which national policies and plans for drinking water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) include measures to improve and extend WASH services to populations disproportionately affected by climate change. The populations disproportionately affected by climate change vary by Party. Measures to improve and extend services include extending services to unserved populations, upgrading existing services, provision of alternative services, and measures to ensure affordability and equitable access to WASH services for all including vulnerable groups.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: High-quality water resources ensure safe drinking water, support adaptive management, and strengthen public health and food security in the face of changing climate patterns. Maintaining and monitoring water body quality is a critical component of adaptation strategies, supporting risk and vulnerability assessment, early warning systems, ecosystem restoration and effective policy decisions for long-term climate resilience.

Indicator name: Percentage of people assisted with the planned relocation in a safe, voluntary, and dignified way among those displaced as a result of water related hazards and extreme events such as floods, droughts, tropical cyclones and storm surges, sea level rise and other water induced disasters
Corresponding sub-target / component: Enhancing climate resilience to water-related hazards
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator assesses the extent to which populations who are displaced as a result of water-related hazards and extreme events are supported with planned reolcation in a safe, voluntary and dignified way. 

Planned relocation in the context of disasters or environmental degradation, including when due to the effects of climate change, is a planned process in which persons or groups of persons move or are assisted to move away from their homes or place of temporary residence, are settled in a new location and provided with the conditions for rebuilding their lives (adapted from Brookings, Georgetown, and UNHCR, 2015). See glossary of the UNFCCC 'Technical Guide on integrating Human Mobility and Climate Change Linkages into Relevant National Climate Change Processes' (pages 9-11)
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Planned relocation is a global phenomenon recognized in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change’s 2010 Cancun Adaptation Framework, the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015–2030, the Nansen Initiative’s 2015 Protection Agenda, and the 2018 Global Compact for Migration. When responses to ongoing sea level rise and land subsidence in low-lying coastal cities and settlements and small islands are aligned with sociocultural values and development priorities, and underpinned by inclusive community engagement processes, they are more effective (high confidence, IPCC 2022 C.2.8).

Providing support for planned relocation ensures displaced populations find safety with dignity. Addressing water-related displacement through organized adaptation reduces trauma and supports long-term recovery. Impacts of water related hazards are considered important outcome indicators. While exposure is important population displacement and economic losses provide the most useful measures of resilience.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 10c Implementation, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10d MEL, 10b Planning, 9c Health
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: Strengthened and inclusive governance, Data and knowledge, Skills and education
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: First step would be to develop metadata and check data availability.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that integrate climate adaptation measures in their national plans for water resources management and water supply and sanitation plans
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by national plans for water resources management and for water supply and for sanitation
Corresponding sub-target / component: Enablers and MoI
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator assesses the extent to which national plans for water resources management and water supply and sanitation integrate climate adaptation measures. It builds on established process indicators with existing guidance and system of reporting on progress towards SDG targets. SDG 6.5.1 country survey assesses the degree of integrated water resources management implementation at national level (0-100) and could be expaned to include implementation of climate adaptation measures. The UN-Water Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking-Water (GLAAS) survey assesses the extent to national water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) plans include climate risk assessment. Adaptation measures are country specific but there are established methods for assessing degrees of implementation.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Integration of climate adaptation measures into national plans for water resources management and water supply and sanitation services enables tailored responses to local water risks, coordinating policies, investments, and actions across municipalities and regions. Such plans ensure water-related hazards are systematically addressed, boosting preparedness and reducing vulnerabilities. This indicator aims to build on established process indicators which have been used to assess the degree to which national plans for water resources management and water supply and sanitation have been implemented and to track the implementation of water-related adaptation measures.
Data availability\n(Description): Baseline data of the original GLAAS indicator for water supply and sanitation plans are available for ~100 countries. However, the data availability for adaptation measures in water resources managemetn plans would need to be checked. Further work required to determine data availability for Parties.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: First step would be to develop metadata and check data availability.

Indicator ID: 9(b) Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production and supply and distribution of food, as well as increasing sustainable and regenerative production and equitable access to adequate food and nutrition for all

Indicator name: Proportion of area under management for food and agricultural production utilising practices and technologies relevant to climate change adaptation
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production, increasing sustainable and regenerative production;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which area under management for food and agricultural production is managed using practices and technologies that enhance resilience and effective response to climate shocks. It tracks the implementation of contextually relevant adaptation measures across different geographies and scales. Qualitative information for this indicator should capture the value chains/ food and agriculture sub sector to which a specific practice is relevant and the climate-related driver or event it responds to.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate change is significantly impacting agricultural production globally, resulting in degradation of the area suitable for agriculture, yield declines, production failures, and agricultural losses which in turn negatively affect livelihoods, economies, and food security. This indicator measures the extent of uptake of measures to help the food and agriculture sector respond to climate shocks, such as soil and water conservation, sustainable irrigation, and agrobiodiversity diversification. It tracks the implementation of context-specific adaptation measures in response to key climate hazards, including drought, flooding, heat stress, soil degradation, and shifting rainfall patterns, with the possibility of aggregation at the global level.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
The definition and classifications of "agricultural land" are available in the SDG indicator 2.4.1 metadata. The suggestion is to expand the SDG 2.4.1 metadata definition of "agricultural land" to include exclusive aquaculture holdings for the purposes of GGA target 9b01. The metrics/sub-indicators measuring the different typologies of "climate-resilient practices and technologies" on agricultural land, including their definitions (taxonomy), data sources and data collection methods would still need to be defined for this indicator.

FAO, AQUASTAT: https://www.fao.org/aquastat/en/#:~:text=AQUASTAT%20is%20the%20FAO%20global,indicators%20by%20country%20from%201960.

World Bank WDI: https://databank.worldbank.org/metadataglossary/world-development-indicators/series/AG.LND.AGRI.ZS&sa=D&source=editors&ust=1756381101470662&usg=AOvVaw06soVBED-dtL0EHc-o2ibJ
Data availability\n(Description): Data sources and data collection already exist for some adaptation-relevant practices (eg. "Use of agrobiodiversity supportive practices") under the SDG indicator 2.4.1 annual questionnaire used since 2020 (http://www.fao.org/sustainabledevelopmentgoals/indicators/241/en/ ). Data is expected to be collected either as part of existing farm surveys or through other data sources such as environmental monitoring systems, administrative data or household surveys
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Further refinement of the metadata is required for operationalization of the indicator, including defining a typology of practices and technologies relevant to climate change adaptation across contexts.Parties will require specific technical and financial support to effectively report on this indicator, building on existing SDG 2.4.1 data collection processes. Guidance is required on how to address the potential risk of double-counting, including how to distinguish area under multiple adaptation practices and technologies.
Remarks: This indicator complements indicators under Target 10d on ecosystems and biodiversity which covers areas in land and water not used for food and agricultural production, including forests and the larger marine and freshwater ecosystems.

Indicator name: Proportion of food and agricultural value chain actors that have adopted practices and technologies relevant to climate change adaptation
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
- Type of food and agriculture sub sector the practice or technology is applicable to (production, processing, supply and distribution, consumption)
- Type of actor (smallholder, commercial/large scale)
- Type of adopted practice or technology
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production, supply and distribution of food
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator measures the rate at which agriculture and food system actors—such as producers, processors, and distributors—are adopting practices and technologies relevant for adapting to experienced or anticipated climate shocks. It tracks the implementation of context-specific adaptation measures that are essential for building the climate resilience of food and agricultural production and food supply and distribution systems, including adjusting planting and harvesting dates, using climate-resilient crops and livestock varieties, implementing sustainable water and pest management, shifting toward more adaptive fisheries and aquaculture practices, adopting improved post-harvest technologies and climate-proofing food storage and infrastructure. 

This indicator complements the information reported under indicator 9b01 ("Proportion of area under management for food and agricultural production under practices and technologies relevant to climate change adaptation") by expanding the coverage of agricultural sub-sectors and stages of the value chain from production to consumption, while focusing on actors as opposed to production area.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: The adoption of climate-resilient agricultural practices, technologies and infrastructure reflects behavioral changes among producers and other agrifood stakeholders aiming to enhance their resilience to climate-related risks, such as droughts, floods, storms and pest outbreaks that can lead to crop losses or damages to productive infrastructure. This indicator provides essential insights into whether adaptation practices, technologies and infrastructure are being adopted and adaptive capacities are being increased across all agricultural sub-sectors, nodes of the agrifood value chain and amongst all typologies of agrifood actors. Adoption rates also serve as a proxy for the effectiveness of policy incentives, climate information services, and farmer training programs.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: N/A
Data availability\n(Description): There is only existing information relating some of the themes described under this indicator. The required taxonomy to list and describe specific agricultural practices, technologies and infrastructures would be based on existing IPCC and FAO publications. Further work is still needed to define metadata.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Further refinement of the definition of suitable metrics under each option for disaggregation under this indicator is still needed and consequently, the development of detailed metadata for this indicator, practically from scratch; this should include a clear definition (taxonomy) of climate-resilient agricultural practices, technologies and infrastructures. Parties will require specific technical and financial support to effectively report on this indicator.

Indicator name: Number of institutional frameworks for knowledge transfer, research and development, and extension services supporting climate change adaptation in food and agriculture
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
- Type of food and agriculture subsector (crop, livestock, fisheries, agroforestry)
- Type of institutional frameworks (R&D, extension services, NAP, community-based organisation, farmer group, agricultural research initiative, science-policy frameworks)
- Type of value chain actor (producer, processor, distributor, marketer)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production, supply and distribution of food, increasing sustainable and regenerative production
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The indicator assesses the extent of knowledge development and capacity building efforts made to support climate change adaptation. A strong framework involves effective collaboration between public and private entities, including universities, research centers, government agencies, extension services, technology demonstration projects and farmer groups.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: The rationale for tracking the number of institutional frameworks for knowledge transfer, research and development (R&D), and extension services in food and agriculture is to measure the capacity and effectiveness of institutions to support climate change adaptation within this critical sector. By counting these frameworks, it's possible to assess whether the necessary infrastructure is in place to help farmers and communities adjust to climate change.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: UNFCCC (capacity building)
Data availability\n(Description): NAPs, agricultural sector reports. Partie reports of plans on adaptation of Food and Agriculture to Climate Change
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Additional support is needed to develop metadata for defining institutional framework, criteria for identifying these frameworks that support climate adaptation, and then systematically collect and quantify them across relevant national or sub-national government bodies, research institutions, and NGOs within the agriculture sector.

Indicator name: Proportion of Parties that have integrated climate risks into national food security measures, programs, and policies
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: - Type of food and agriculture subsector (crop, livestock, fisheries, agroforestry)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing equitable access to adequate food and nutrition
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The indicator assesses the presence of institutional safety nets, emergency and anticipatory and contingency plans to prevent food insecurity during climate shocks, which include investments into accessible and adequate food reserves and storage.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: The indicator provides a crucial measure of a Party's institutional readiness in the context of adaptation and strategic intent to build a climate-resilient food systems. It moves beyond planning and rhetoric to assess the tangible financial and operational dedication of a Party's entire governmental structure (national to local level) to safeguarding its agricultural sector and food security from climate impacts.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: N/A
Data availability\n(Description): Database needs to be developed
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards, and data from Parties are currently unavailable. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Amount of climate adaptation finance disbursed to food and agriculture per year
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: - Different channels (bilateral, multilateral, regional); - Financial instruments (grant, concessional loan, non-concessional loan, equity, guarantee, insurance, other); - Type of value chain actors receiving finance; - Type of programmes or projects
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production and supply and distribution of food, as well as increasing  equitable access to adequate food and nutrition for all
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the finance from various sources disbursed to actors in food and agriculture for the implementation of projects and actions related to climate adaptation.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator tracks the annual financial resources specifically disbursed to enhance climate adaptation within the entire food and agriculture value chain. It is critical because achieving meaningful adaptation—from implementing resilient farming practices to building robust, climate-smart storage and processing infrastructure—requires substantial and targeted investment. By quantifying these disbursements, this indicator serves as a direct measure of financial commitment and flow, revealing whether funding is adequately reaching all sectors and stages necessary to transition towards a climate-resilient food system.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: International and national data on projects and programmes
Data availability\n(Description): Sourced from OECD DAC Creditor Reporting System (CRS), Climate Funds Update (GCF, Adaptation Funds), MDB Joint Reports on Climate Finance, CPI;
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: A universally adopted standard for defining and reporting adaptation finance is lacking which leads to inconsistencies across different institutions and reports. It would need to be developed and esablished to operationalize this indicator.

Indicator name: Proportion of area under management for food and agricultural production degraded due to climate-related drivers and events
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production  increasing sustainable and regenerative production;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator assesses the decline or loss of productive capacity of land and water, rendering them less suitable for food and agricultural production, considering all critical subsectors, including crops, livestock, agroforestry, as well as inland and marine-based aquaculture. Degradation means a persistent decline as assessed through biophysical elements such as long-term decline in Net Primary Productivity (NPP), soil organic carbon loss, increased soil erosion, desertification, deviation from ambient water temperature, salinity, among others. To properly understand and contextualize the data from this indicator, it is essential for reporting to show the specific elements considered in defining degradation, the dominant climate drivers, and value chains and social groups most impacted.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator is crucial for understanding the impacts of climate-related drivers and events on natural resources critical for food and agricultural production, which in turn affects production and ultimately food security. In relation to land, the indicator considers the multifaceted aspects of land degradation, including soil properties, vegetation cover, and water retention capacity. For marine aquaculture, decline in ocean pH and oxygen levels, warming waters, and ocean acidification have been shown to reduce productivity. For inland aquaculture, salinity intrusion, rapid temperature changes, and algal blooms have direct effects on fish production.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The definition and classifications of "agricultural land" are available in the SDG indicator 2.4.1 metadata. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-15-03-01.pdf / "water quality" refers to ambient water quality in rivers, lakes, and groundwater, measured by SDG indicator 6.3.2, which tracks the proportion of water bodies that meet good ambient water quality standards.
Data availability\n(Description): Data sources and data collection already exist under the SDG indicator 15.3.1: Proportion of land that is degraded over total land (https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-15-03-01.pdf), and SDG indicator 6.3.2: Proportion of bodies of water with good ambient water quality (https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-06-03-02.pdf ). Data is expected to be collected either as part of existing farm surveys or through other data sources such as environmental monitoring systems, administrative data or household surveys Data is expected to be collected either as part of existing farm surveys or through other data sources such as environmental monitoring systems, administrative data or household surveys
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Further refinement of the metadata is required for operationalization of the indicator, including defining the climate-relevant drivers of land and water degradation. Parties will require specific technical and financial support to effectively report on this indicator, building on existing SDG 15.3.1

Indicator name: Reduction in food and agricultural yield associated with climate-related drivers and events
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: - Type of food and agriculture subsector (crop, livestock, fisheries, agroforestry)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the percentage increase or decrease in yield from key crops, livestock, and fisheries that is associated with climate-related drivers and events such as droughts, floods, pests and diseases, heat stress, among others. The framing of the indicator is general enough to allow Parties to capture specific crops, livestock, and fisheries value chains relevant for their context. In addition to providing aggregate figures of change, Parties can also provide qualitative information such as the specific crops and livestock species affected, the main climate impact drivers (hazards, capacities), and the geographical locations or social groups that are most affected.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator is highly relevant for understanding the impacts of climate-related events on food and agricultural production, in turn demonstrating the resilience of these systems. A high proportion of yield loss linked to climate change and variability signals that current agricultural systems are not resilient. The core concept of measuring yield deviation from a climate-adjusted baseline is universally applicable, making the indicator suitable for global assessment and aggregation. Nevertheless, the indicator allows Parties to provide contextually relevant information.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/QCL
https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.PRD.FOOD.XD
Data availability\n(Description): FAOSTAT provides crop and livestock statistics are recorded for 278 products
Units:
Unit will depend on the context specific sub-sectors of food and agriculture production. 
Examples:
Crops: Tonnes per Hectare 
Livestock (Meat): Litres (milk) per animal per year’ (different animals can also be converted to livestock units)
Livestock (Dairy): Kilograms (butter) per animal per year OR ‘Litres (milk) per animal per year’
Poultry (Eggs): Eggs per laying hen per year
Poultry (meat): Kg per bird/hen per year
Aquaculture: Tonnes per Hectare per year 
Fisheries (Wild): Catch Per Unit Effort (CPUE) (e.g., tonnes per vessel tonnage)
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Parties might require specific technical support to effectively report on this indicator.

Indicator name: Prevalence of undernourishment associated with climate-related drivers and events
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing equitable access to adequate food and nutrition
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the proportion of the population whose caloric intake is insufficient to provide the dietary energy levels that are required to maintain a normal, active, and healthy life. The focus of this universally accepted indicator is explicitly on the association of climate-related drivers and events in increasing the prevalence of undernourishment with a focus on hazard prone areas.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate change is resulting in an increased number of undernourished people. In addition to assessing the vulnerability of populations and the climate change impacts on food intake, this indicator is essential for measuring the extent to which adaptation efforts such as nutritional intervention programmes and other social protection programmes, early warning systems, and changes in local food systems (shift to more resilient practices) have reduced undernourishment prevalence, especially in hazard-prone areas/hotspots. This indicator enables tracking whether adaptation efforts translate improved nourishment outcomes for the most affected populations.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-02-01-01.pdf
Data availability\n(Description):
Food consumption surveys collected for SDG 2.1.1 since 2017

https://www.fao.org/sustainable-development-goals-data-portal/data/indicators/2.1.1-prevalence-of-undernourishment/en
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Parties might require specific technical support to effectively report on this indicator.

Indicator name: Prevalence of moderate or severe food insecurity associated with climate-related drivers and events
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing equitable access to adequate food and nutrition
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the change in the percentage of the population experiencing moderate or severe food insecurity associated with climate change. This indicator focuses on a broader spectrum of intermediate dimensions by considering the association of climate shocks to reduced availability, distribution, and affordability of food. In addition to reporting on computed overall prevalence, disaggregated information can be provided to by social groups and geographies that are most impacted by climate change.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate change is already negatively affecting food and nutrition security through both direct impacts of slow onset aspects (change in temperature, precipitation patterns, dry spells, droughts, changes in seasonality, salinization of soils in coastal areas, coastal habitat loss etc.) and rapid onset extreme events (i.e., heavy precipitations, heatwaves, floods, pest outbreaks etc.). There are multiple transmission channels through which these impacts materialise including impacts on crop yields, on agricultural labour and therefore crop production and agricultural income, on non-agricultural labour and non-agricultural income, on health and the ability to earn enough to afford food, on food prices and therefore the affordability of food, and on food supply chains and therefore the variety of food. Tracking changes in the prevalence of food insecurity associated with climate change can enable the design and targeting of safety nets (food and/or cash) and other interventions to strengthen resilience.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-02-01-02.pdf 

https://www.lse.ac.uk/granthaminstitute/projects/climate-food-insecurity-lab/tracking-the-impact-of-climate-change-on-food-insecurity/
Data availability\n(Description):
Updated annually (2014 onwards)

https://lancetcountdown.org/explore-our-data/
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Parties might require specific technical support to effectively report on this indicator. This indicator uses FAO Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES) data combined with methodology from the food security and undernutrition indicator from the Lancet Countdown and LSE Food (In)security Lab. The computations can be performed by the indicator authors and made available to the parties.

Indicator name: Direct agricultural losses associated with climate-related drivers and events
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: - Type of food and agriculture sub sectors (crop, livestock, fisheries, agroforestry)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining climate-resilient food and agricultural production and supply and distribution, increasing equitable access to adequate food and nutrition for all
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator aims to quantify the value of losses in food and agriculture associated with climate-related drivers and events. it includes production losses and reduced yields across subsectors and value chains, for instance, due to the destruction of crops, reduced livestock health and increased mortality, reduced fish catch, among others. It considers impacts across the entire agricultural value chain, from production to distribution losses associated with destruction of key assets and infrastructure.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator provides a concrete and quantifiable measure of the immediate economic impact of climate-related drivers and events on food and agriculture. By systematically recording the monetary value of lost crops, livestock, agroforestry and aquaculture, this indicator provides insights into the vulnerability and resilience of the food and agriculture sector to climate shocks - a resilient and well-adapted system, as well as a reduction of climate shocks, would be indicated by a decline in economic impacts. The universality of the indicator makes it suitable for assessing climate impacts and adaptation at the global level while allowing Parties to report on the contextually-relevant impacts and losses which can then be aggregated globally.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Sendai C-2 would be considered a starting point "Direct agricultural loss attributed to disasters. Agriculture is understood to include the crops, livestock, fisheries, apiculture, aquaculture and forest sectors as well as associated facilities and infrastructure". The definition of "disaster" could not be only linked to extreme events (https://www.undrr.org/terminology/disaster). The main challenge are (1) defining how to determine climate attribution (2) calculation of indirect losses

Existing FAO methodology (without climate attribution) https://openknowledge.fao.org/items/5bc863c3-618d-48c8-92ce-26842444855f
Data availability\n(Description): https://www.undrr.org/building-risk-knowledge/disaster-losses-and-damages-tracking-system-dts
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Parties will require specific technical and financial support to effectively report on this indicator. The expert community is working on common methodological approaches for reporting under this metrics, considering the climate attribution element

Indicator ID: 9(c) Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts, promoting climate-resilient health services and significantly reducing climate-related morbidity and mortality, particularly in the most vulnerable communities
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator captures the change in the deaths that can be epidemiologically associated to heat exposure, witht the purpose of capturing a reduction in heat-related mortality as an outcome of adaptation. It uses well-established methodologies that are regularly used by some countries and most epidemiological studies for estimating heat-related deaths. However, to ensure it is able to reflect adaptation progress, it modifies these models by using time-varying relative risk. As data input, it uses daily, weekly, or monthly mortality data, and meteorological or climate reanalysis data when the former are not available. These data sources are frequently available at a national and sub-national level. The baseline for the reporting of change will be established considering the time range of data availability for monitoring heat-related mortality across most countries

Indicator name: Change in the rate of mortality associated with heat exposure
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts; and significantly reducing climate-related morbidity and mortality, particularly in the most vulnerable communities
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks changes in the incidence of climate-sensitive infectious diseases per 100,000 population for dengue, chikungunya, zika, tick-borne encephalitis (TBE), West Nile fever (WNF), malaria and diarrheal diseases over time as part of a time series.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: As heat exposure increases, adaptation efforts are needed to prevent heat-related morbidity and mortality. Even in colder latitudes, heat exposure is becoming a prominent problem, especially as human-made systems and infrastructure are unprepared to withstand heat. Heat protection requires specific and tailored approaches, and many countries are taking measures to reduce heat-related health impacts. This indicator is therefore globally applicable. It's disaggregation by vulnerable groups (including vulnerable age groups, gender, socioeconomic groups, and Indigenous People) will also help capture whether adaptation is being effective at protecting the most at-risk populations, and will increase the sensitivity of the indicator in capturing adaptation progress. By focusing on the change in the rate of heat-related mortality, this indicator will allow countries to capture progress on adaptation to heat. While mortality is the most extreme outcome of heat exposure, this indicator was chosen as it can be constructed using data that is available in most countries (mainly all-cause deaths at high geographical and temporal resolution, and disaggregated by relevant groups). Assessing the change in heat-related mortality acts as a robust proxy to understand whether health adaptation to heat is taking place effectively.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: This indicator builds on well-established indicators, available from many sources, including the UK Office of National Statistics SOSCHI project and the Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change. However, it needs to be modified to ensure it can be sensitive to adaptation progress. The expert group is prepared to develop the metadata and detailed methodologies and tools to support Parties in the development of this indicator.
Data availability\n(Description): As heat exposure increases, adaptation efforts are needed to prevent heat-related morbidity and mortality. Even in colder latitudes, heat exposure is becoming a prominent problem, especially as human-made systems and infrastructure are unprepared to withstand heat. Heat protection requires specific and tailored approaches, and many countries are taking measures to reduce heat-related health impacts. This indicator is therefore globally applicable. It's disaggregation by vulnerable groups (including vulnerable age groups, gender, socioeconomic groups, local communities, and Indigenous Peoples) will also help capture whether adaptation is being effective at protecting the most at-risk populations, and will increase the sensitivity of the indicator in capturing adaptation progress. By focusing on the change in the rate of heat-related mortality, this indicator will allow Parties to capture progress on adaptation to heat. While mortality is the most extreme outcome of heat exposure, this indicator was chosen as it can be constructed using data that is available in most countries (mainly all-cause deaths at high geographical and temporal resolution, and disaggregated by relevant groups). Assessing the change in heat-related mortality acts as a robust proxy to understand whether health adaptation to heat is taking place effectively.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: This indicator needs to be developed based on modified methodologies. The expert group is able to support the development of tools for Parties to report this indicator. However, it would need to be operationalised at a national level. Depending on the availability of all-cause mortality data at the required level of temporal and geographical resolution, and with the adequate disaggregation, the indicator could be processed at a global level. While there is no custodian agency defined as of yet, the expert group can support in the development of the indicator.

Indicator name: Change in the incidence of climate-sensitive infectious diseases (dengue, chikungunya, zika, tick-borne encephalitis (TBE), West Nile fever (WNF), malaria and diarrheal diseases)
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Geographic, Climate-related hazards, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
By disease: dengue, chikungunya, zika, tick-borne encephalitis (TBE), West Nile fever (WNF), malaria and diarrheal diseases;
by age, sex, and ethnicity.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts.
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks injuries and mortality due to heat stress at work.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: All these diseases are highly climate-sensitive (based on the peer-reviewed literature) and have a high disease burden in certain countries. Since the incidence of these diseases vary by Party, different diseases can be recorded, according to the disease burden in the respective country but can later be disaggregated by disease. Moreover, changes in climatic suitability for disease transmission will also be reported, stratified by disease. Relating a change in the incidence of a climate-sensitive disease, to a change in the climatic suitability, can give an indication of the effectiveness of adaptation interventions. For example, an incidence-decrease, but a climatic suitability increase (due to climate change), is an indication that the adaptation intervention works.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Case definition for these diseases can be found at WHO or here: https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32018D0945&from=EN.  A change in climatic suitability can be computed by specific disease category: for example. for arboviruses it can be computed as follows: Annual average transmission risk (basic reproduction number [R0]) of Ae albopictus and Ae aegypti for 2014–23 compared to 1951–60. For WNV it would be: WNV–R0 in 2014–23, compared with 1951–60, in the regions where the three Culex mosquitoes occur.  The climatic suitability for TBE it would be months of suitable activity compared to baseline.
Data availability\n(Description): Many of these diseases are reportable and are available at the country level if they are of public health concern. WHO does also collect the incidence of these diseases. The climatic suitability of these diseases at the country level can be computed centrally. For example, by the Climate-Sensitive Infectious Diseases lab in Heidelberg: https://csidlab.iwr.uni-heidelberg.de/
Units: Annual change (%) in incidence rate of each disease per 100,000 population
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The climatic suitability for dengue, chikungunya, zika, tick-borne encephalitis (TBE), West Nile virus (WNV) and malaria has been described in detail here: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39488222/  (see methods section) and computations can be performed centrally by the Climate-Sensitive Infectious Diseases lab in Heidelberg: https://csidlab.iwr.uni-heidelberg.de/.

Indicator name: Change in the annual rate of reported heat-related occupational injuries and deaths
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Climate-related hazards
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This monitors the provision of mental and psychosocial health support specifically for climate change-sensitive events, making it relevant to climate change adaptation. This indicator would ask Parties about their provision of MHPSS in the face of climate change-sensitive events of local relevance. The events each Party would provide services for depends on local climate change hazards, but would include both extreme weather events, as well as slow-onset events (e.g., sea level rise or agricultural losses), and climate-sensitive infectious disease outbreaks. The indicator will be based on a survey which will ask a series of structured questions about the status of MHPSS. These will include: (1) Whether the health system adaptation for climate change plan includes a plan or strategy for the implementation of MHPSS in response to climate change impacts; (2) Whether there is dedicated financial and human resources for the MHPSS plans or strategy; (3) Whether the MHPSS plans or strategy is being implemented; and (4) Whether the MHPSS plan has built in monitoring and evaluation through defined indicators and targets.
The answers to each of these questions build a qualitative score per Party. The global indicator would average the score of all Parties, to produce a global score on the level of mental health and psychosocial support delivered globally.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Workers exposed to extreme heat at work experience occupational heat stress which increases the risk of heat-related illnesses, injuries, and deaths, making this indicator a critical measure of climate impacts on vulnerable labor populations. This indicator tracks the incidences of injuries and mortality as a result of heat exposure on the job. Tracking changes in heat-related occupational injuries and deaths reflects the workforce's vulnerability to climate change and the effectiveness of adaptation measures such as heat safety regulations, early warning systems, and workplace modifications that reduce heat exposure or risks. As such, monitoring heat-related occupational health outcomes provides actionable data on where and when to intensify adaptation efforts like workplace cooling, schedule adjustments, hydration protocols, and public health outreach to protect worker health under warming conditions.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: https://www.ilo.org/sites/default/files/2024-07/ILO_OSH_Heatstress-R16.pdf
Data availability\n(Description): Country-level data from the ILO.
Units: Rate of injuries and deaths per 100,000 workers
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: This indicator could be be operationalised in collaboration with agencies collecting data on occupational injuries and mortality.

Indicator name: Extent of implementation of Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) preparedness and response for climate change-sensitive events
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Wherever possible, the indicator should be disaggregated at a sub-national level, and specify whether MHPSS services are provided in regions in which Indigenous Peoples predominantly live.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator is modified from SDG targets 1.5, 11.5 and 13.1 (aligned with Sendai Framework Target D). It measures the health infrastructure damages and disruptions, a crucial element to ensure health resilience. 
While the indicator captures the absolute number, the analysis is recommended to be done over years to capture change over time to understand and track adaptation effectiveness. This indicator complements the indicator 9c06, that captures information on health facilities built or retrofitted, and the two indicators together provide a comprehensive information on the level of health system resilience against climate change.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Extreme weather events related to climate change have been shown to adversely affect mental health. The availability of adequate responses to protect mental health in the face of climate change is essential for adequate health adaptation. This indicator builds on the WHO's approach towards mental health promotion, adapting it to climate change-related events, to track whether essential mental and psychosocial health support is in place, increasing health resilience to climate change. The indicator is relevant to adaptation as it monitors the implementation of adaptation interventions to reduce the impact of climate change on mental and psychosocial health. Given the impacts of climate change on mental health are observed in every Party, and are often associated to the impacts of climate change on physical health and on socioeconomic conditions, or to the exposure to climate-related disasters, the protection of mental health from climate hazards is therefore of global relevance.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata needs to be developed for this indicator. This includes developing a questionnaire with specific sub-questions needed to build the score. These will be based around: (1) Whether the MHPSS is within the plans for health system adaptation for climate change; (2) Whether MHPSS plans are financed; (3) Whether MHPSS plans are implemented; and (4) Whether MHPSS plans have built in monitoring and evaluation through defined indicators and targets
Data availability\n(Description): The data will need to be collected and reported by Parties, through responses to a survey. This data collection and reporting will be in alignment with the collection of responses for other surveys that ministries of health regularly respond to.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The indicator has not been agreed with the WHO, which sometimes requires extensive consultation with member states. Its operationalisation through a survey to Ministries of Health makes this indicator feasible, although the details of how the survey will be rolled out still need to be defined.

Indicator name: Number of destroyed or damaged health facilities and number of disruptions to health services associated with climate-related events
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Climate-related hazards
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Parties may also provide information on proportion of health facilities built or retrofitted to be climate resilient based on national, regional, or global guidance.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Health-related impacts and climate-resilient health systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the proportion of health facilities built or retrofitted to be climate resilient based on national, regional, or global guidance. This indicator uses data from the WHO's survey for the General Programme of Work 14 and builds on a question asked to parties, where they re requried to report on the percetage of health facilities built or retrofitted to be climate resilient based on national, regional or global guidance.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This indicator monitors the health aspect of climate change adaptation capacity and analyzed with time-series to capture its change over time. The indicator is key to undetrstanding the level of climate-resilient infrastructure or systems in place to ensure service continuity during climate-related events. 
With growing number and intensifying climate-related disasters, the continuation of functioning health facility and health services become ever more important. Change over time tracks the adaptation effectiveness of the health sector services and infrastructure against climate-related disasters.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: This indicator is modified from a Sendai Framework target and its metadata is readily available at the Technical Guidance of Sendai Framework
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015. As of 2025, 117 countries have reported infrastructure damages.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: UNDRR will support countries developing the new Disaster Tracking System (DTS) to collect data on this indicator, provide capacity and technical support on methodologies, and improve data governance. Further support will be needed to provide the desired level of disaggregation.

Indicator name: Percentage of health facilities built or retrofitted to be climate resilient based on national, regional or global guidance
Corresponding sub-target / component: Health-related impacts and climate-resilient health systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The coverage of essential health services (defined as the average coverage of essential services based on tracer interventions that include reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access, among the general and the most disadvantaged population). The indicator is an index reported on a unitless scale of 0 to 100, which is computed as the geometric mean of 14 tracer indicators of health service coverage. The tracer indicators are as follows, organized by four components of service coverage: 1. Reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health 2. Infectious diseases 3. Noncommunicable diseases 4. Service capacity and access.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Climate hazards affect the health of people and the facilities built to protect health. Thus, it is relevant to measure the percentage of health facilities built or retrofitted to be climate resilient based on national, regional, or global guidance. This indiacator monitors the percentage of healthcare facilities that have been retrofitted to withstand increased climate change hazards. This is essential for the protection of those wihtin the facilities and to ensure the continuation of healthcare provision and service delivery.

This indicator supports climate adaptation, informs resilient design and retrofitting, and guides resource allocation to protect critical healthcare services, and to allow to ensure climate resilience and environmental sustainability.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The metadata is available from the WHO climate change and health survey, although the survey has not yet been made publicly available.
Data availability\n(Description): Data will be available as countries respond to the WHO Climate Change and Health Survey
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: WHO provides guidance and collects data from countries of their implementation

Indicator name: Universal Health Coverage (UHC): Coverage of essential health services (SDG 3.8.1)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts, promoting climate-resilient health services and significantly reducing climate-related morbidity and mortality, particularly in the most vulnerable communities
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This is a key global health indicator collected by all countries. Universal health coverage means that all people and communities receive the health services they need and of sufficient quality to be effective while also ensuring that the use of these services does not expose the user to financial hardship. It covers the full continuum of essential health services, from health promotion to prevention, treatment, rehabilitation and palliative care across the life course. Climate change intensifies existing health burdens and introduces new challenges and increases the frequency and severity of extreme weather events that can damage health infrastructure and disrupt service delivery. Strong UHC systems build resilience by maintaining continuity of care during climate shocks, supporting vulnerable populations disproportionately affected by climate hazards, and enabling effective emergency preparedness and response. By tracking progress in UHC, this indicator provides a measure of whether adaptation is translating into equitable, affordable, and continuous access to quality health services.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: https://data.who.int/indicators/i/3805B1E/9A706FD
Data availability\n(Description): Available from WHO: https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/topics/service-coverage
Units: Index reported on a unitless scale of 0 to 100
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: WHO provides guidance and collects data from countries of their implementation

Indicator name: Level of operationalisation of climate-informed health early warning systems for climate change-related health risks accessible to vulnerable groups
Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts, promoting climate-resilient health services
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator is based on the WHO Climate Change and Health Survey, which all WHO Member States are invited to respond. The survey asks Member States a series of questions regarding the status of implementation of EWSs for each of the health risks that are relevant to each Party, which serve to indicate the extent of operationalisation. These questions include (1) whether a Climate-Informed health EWS allowing the prediction of specific health risks is available; whether climate-informed health EWS includes a mechanism to communicate early warnings to general public in a timely manner based on pre-defined warning thresholds; and whether there is a health sector response plan in place. For the construction of this indicator, each of this questions will receive a score following the methodology used by the WHO in the analysis of Survey results. Scores will be averaged for the different diseases. The global indicator will report the average score for all Parties.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate influences the transmission of many infectious diseases, some of which being among the most important causes of death and morbidity in developing countries. Commonly, these diseases occur as epidemics which may be triggered by variations in climatic conditions that imply higher transmission rates. Strengthening EWS for climate sensitive health hazards becomes fundamental under conditions of rapid global environmental change. EWS are tools for detecting and predicting an impending disease outbreak, and delivering accessible warnings to relevant populations, thereby triggering early health-protective responses. EWS is an information system designed to support decision- making of national and local-level institutions to enable vulnerable groups in society to take action to mitigate the impacts of an impending risk. EWS help improve coordination among relevant stakeholders, such as local epidemiologists, meteorologists, entomologists, the national and local management agencies that assess risk and develop response strategies, and the public communication channels used to disseminate warning information. Effective risk monitoring and EWS can prevent illness, injury and death when coupled with adequate communication and response capacity. The use of EWS can increase the effectiveness of disease control by intervening before or at the beginning of the epidemic curve. The core elements of climate-informed EWS are to: (i) monitor environmental conditions; (ii) forecast high-risk conditions, initiate active surveillance; (iii) send alerts and communication; and (iv) establish a mechanism for early response.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The metadata is available from the WHO climate change and health survey, although the survey has not yet been made publicly available. The methodology for scoring the answers and building a unique metric for the global indicator is yet to be developed, but would be a simple addition to the survey questions.
Data availability\n(Description): WHO climate and health survey 2025
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: WHO provides guidance and collects data from Parties of their implementation

Indicator name: Level of implementation of climate change and health vulnerability and adaptation assessment
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By types of government agency/ministries
