Corresponding sub-target / component: Attaining resilience against climate change related health impacts; and significantly reducing climate-related morbidity and mortality, particularly in the most vulnerable communities
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator monitors the extent of implementation of climate change and health vulnerability assessments, by drawing on the questions included in the WHO climate change and health survey. the survey asks Parties (1) whether an assessment has been completed, is under development, is planned, or is not planed or not available; (2) whether the Ministry of Health has endorsed it; (3)  the extent to which the findings of the assessment result in development of new health policies or programmes, or the revision of existing health policies or programmes; (4) . Whether the findings of the assessment were used to inform the development of the Partiy's climate change and health policies and processes; and (5) Whether the results of the assessment influenced the allocation of human and financial resources within the Ministry of Health to address health risks of climate change. The answers to these questions will be scored, and the average score for each Party will be used to build a global score
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Vulnerability and adaptation assessments are done by Parties following well established WHO guidance (https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240036383). WHO collects this information therefore it is readily available. It is a key health adaptation indicator.A V&A assessment is a participatory process. It is a tool that allows Parties to evaluate which populations and specific geographies are most vulnerable to different kinds of health effects from climate change; to identify weaknesses in the systems that should protect them; and to specify interventions to respond.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The metadata is available from the WHO climate change and health survey, although the survey has not yet been made publicly available. The methodology for scoring the answers and building a unique metric for the global indicator is yet to be developed, but would be a simple addition to the survey questions.
Data availability\n(Description): Country reports received by WHO for analysis
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: WHO provides guidance and collects data from Parties of their implementation

Indicator name: Proportion of the ministry in charge of health's workforce that has received training on climate change and health in the last two years
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By type of hazard response that training was provided for
Corresponding sub-target / component: Promoting climate-resilient health services
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator is based on the WHO Climate Change and Health survey, which asks Parties to indicate the percentage of the Ministry of Health Workforce that has received training on climate change and health in the past two years.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: The health workforce is key to adaptation, building climate resilience and environmental sustainability of health systems. Increased health workforce capacity will help health systems to adapt by responding to risks associated with climate change. Health workforce competencies can be developed through pre-service education, lifelong learning, and mentoring. Skills required include understanding and using climate information for health interventions and decision-making; engaging in cross-sectoral action; conducting research, assessments, and interventions; and effectively managing climate change risks to health and health system performance. A health system relies upon an effective health workforce to achieve the best health outcomes possible, given available resources and circumstances. Climate change may increase local demand for health services, thus potentially altering the number of health workers required, the skills mix of health workers needed, as well as their competencies. The availability of the required health and care workforce with the required capacity to act on climate change and health is a fundamental determinant of overall climate resilience as it strongly predicts the capacity of health systems to provide health services in a changing
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The metadata is available from the WHO climate change and health survey, although the survey has not yet been made publicly available.
Data availability\n(Description): Data will be available as Parties respond to the WHO Climate Change and Health Survey
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: WHO provides guidance and collects data from Parties (for Ministry of Health workforce) of their implementation

Indicator ID: 9(d) Reducing climate impacts on ecosystems and biodiversity, and accelerating the use of ecosystem-based adaptation and nature-based solutions, including through their management, enhancement, restoration and conservation and the protection of terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems;

Indicator name: Proportion of population with secured access to provisioning services from ecosystems that support adaptive capacity
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: (1) by ecosystem type: terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems, and all other relevant ecosystems as applicable
Corresponding sub-target / component: accelerating the use of ecosystem-based adaptation and nature-based solutions
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the proportion of the population whose livelihoods and basic needs are supported by ecosystems (including food, freshwater, fibre, wild foods, and fisheries) in ways that are climate-resilient and sustainable. It is defined as the proportion (percentage) of the population with secured access to provisioning ecosystem services that remain reliable under climate change scenarios.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Ecosystems of all types play a critical role in ensuring water supply, food security, and livelihood stability, making it globally applicable to all Parties. Ecosystems directly support livelihood resilience, reduce vulnerability to climate-induced shocks, and underpin ecosystem-based adaptation strategies. By measuring secured access to these key services, the indicator provides a direct measure of a population's adaptive capacity, reflecting their ability to cope with and respond to climate impacts by relying on natural assets. It moves beyond assessing vulnerability to measuring the proactive capacity of people to adapt.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
This indicator builds on the IUCN “services provided by ecosystems” (GBF Indicator B-1) and applies the System of Environmental-Economic Accounting (SEEA) framework, which provides standards for compiling accounts of provisioning services such as food, freshwater, fibre, and wild resources. Existing methodologies, including SEEA water accounts and agriculture – forestry – fisheries modules, enable countries to track the sustainable use and availability of these services under climate stress. Ecosystem service models such as InVEST and ARIES can generate biophysical and spatial estimates of provisioning flows, complementing national statistical data and household surveys, thereby strengthening the measurement of climate-resilient provisioning services in a consistent and comparable way across Parties.
See link: https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/B-1
Data availability\n(Description): Data availability for provisioning services is supported by national statistical agencies through household surveys and water accounts and global datasets from FAO on agriculture, fisheries, and forestry. SEEA pilot ecosystem accounts and model outputs from tools like InVEST also provide valuable estimates of provisioning flows. The coverage is high in developed countries. There are data gaps in LDCs and SIDS.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Provisioning services can be assessed using SEEA Ecosystem Accounting and ecosystem service models such as InVEST or ARIES, combine these results with household survey data to estimate the share of the population benefitting, and aggregate findings at regional and global levels. Technical, technological, and financial support could be sought from international organizations such as FAO, WFP, UNSD, and UNFCCC.
Remarks: This indicator links ecosystems to human well-being, particularly food and water security. Further work is needed to standardize methods for measuring secured access and resilience across Parties and contexts.  This indicator could also report in multiple units. In addition to the primary unit, secondary units could include: volume (m³ water/year), tons/year (food/fibre/fisheries), USD/year (monetary valuation).  The metadata when developed will fully outlined the various intermediary services under this indicator and this will clarify the units.

Indicator name: Extent and capacity of regulating ecosystem services that reduce exposure and vulnerability to climate risks/impacts
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: (1) by ecosystem type: terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems, and all other relevant ecosystems as applicable
Corresponding sub-target / component:
reducing climate impacts on ecosystems and biodiversity;
accelerating the use of ecosystem-based adaptation and nature-based solutions.
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures (a) the extent (area, distribution) of ecosystems that provide regulating services critical for climate risk reduction, and (b) their capacity (biophysical ability) to sustain those services under current conditions and climate change scenarios. It reflects both the spatial coverage of regulating ecosystems and their functional ability to reduce climate risks and impacts.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Multiple ecosystems contribute to retaining floodwater, preventing soil erosion, stabilizing coastlines, purifying water, and reducing risk of sea level rise. The indicator is globally relevant as the regulating services are critical climate-induced shocks in all contexts and especially in vulnerable contexts and countries. It directly links healthy ecosystems to reduced exposure, disaster risk reduction, and resilience. This includes contributions of wetlands, forests, floodplains, grasslands, reefs, mangroves, seagrass, and others.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9f Poverty & livelihoods
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: This indicator builds on the IUCN “services provided by ecosystems” (GBF Indicator B-1) and leverages the System of Environmental-Economic Accounting (SEEA) Ecosystem Accounting framework, which includes modules for regulating services such as water retention and soil stabilization. In addition, ecosystem service models like InVEST and ARIES provide biophysical quantification that can complement national accounts and fill data gaps, enabling consistent and comparable measurement of regulating services across countries.  see link https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/B-1
Data availability\n(Description): Global and regional datasets exist from remote sensing and in situ, eg, on wetlands, forests, and coastal, ocean and marine ecosystems, as well as hydrological and erosion models that estimate flood retention, soil loss prevention, and coastal protection. National disaster risk reduction, hazard models and Earth System Models also provide relevant information. Coverage is higher at the global level and lower in developing countries, particularly LDCs and SIDS.
Units:
For extent, percent (%)
The measurement unit for this indicator is the spatial extent (hectares or km2) expressed as the proportion (%) of extent of regulating ecosystem services over total extent.
For capacity, the measurement unit is in biophysical or functional units (m³/year, tons/year, km²/year, %, W/m², °C), depending on the regulating service assessed.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Regulating service flows cen be estimated using SEEA Ecosystem Accounting and hazard models such as ARIES for SEEA or InVEST for flood mitigation and sediment retention, linking ecosystem extent and condition data directly to hazard risk reduction outcomes with technical, technological, and financial support from international organizations such as UNEP, UNSD, and UNFCCC. These results can be aggregated at national, regional, and global levels to track progress consistently.
Remarks: Relevant for disaster risk reduction related to climate change. Adaptation-focused reporting needs strengthening to ensure comparability and integration into national adaptation planning. This indicator could also report in multiple units for both extent and capacity. Extent can be measured in spatial units; ha, km², km, or % of a given type of land area. Capacity could be measured in biophysical or functional units (m³/year, tons/year, km²/year, %, W/m², °C), depending on the regulating service assessed. The metadata when developed will fully outline the various intermediary services under this indicator and this will clarify the units.

Indicator name: Proportion of populations benefiting from nature- and biodiversity-based cultural services that enhance adaptive capacity
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: (1) by ecosystem type: terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems, and all other relevant ecosystems as applicable
Corresponding sub-target / component: accelerating the use of ecosystem-based adaptation and nature-based solutions
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the proportion of people benefiting from cultural, spiritual, recreational, relational, reciprocal, and knowledge services provided by nature and biodiversity that directly support adaptive capacity. Defined as the percentage of people in communities reporting access to or reliance on nature- and biodiversity-based cultural and knowledge services, it emphasizes the non-material but essential role of ecosystems in sustaining adaptive capacity.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Ecosystems contribute to identity, heritage, Indigenous Knowledge systems, recreation, eco-tourism, and education, all of which build social resilience and support learning, cohesion, and innovation in responding to climate change.The indicator is globally applicable but especially critical for Indigenous Peoples, local communities, and vulnerable populations where cultural and biodiversity-linked practices underpin resilience.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
The metadata for this indicator is linked to the IUCN GBF Indicator B-1 on cultural services, while SEEA Ecosystem Accounting acknowledges cultural services but notes that measurement frameworks are still under development. Current approaches often rely on survey-based and qualitative methods, including community surveys and UNESCO cultural indicators, to capture the social and knowledge dimensions of ecosystem benefits.
See link to CBD: https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/2-2
Data availability\n(Description): Data availability for cultural and knowledge services is limited, with some information collected at the national level through tourism, education, and heritage sectors, and information from household and community surveys, including those from Indigenous Peoples and local communities. There are gaps in coverage and comparability as existing datasets do not systematically capture adaptation-relevant cultural services.
Units: % of people (by level of disaggregation) benefitting.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Data collection from national surveys that assess cultural and knowledge benefits linked to ecosystems, complemented by ecosystem extent and condition accounts modeling using tools such as the InVEST Recreational Access model and through the development of indicators using Indigenous Knowledge can be used. The results can be integrated into national adaptation reporting for the GGA, GST, as well as SDG and GBF monitoring frameworks.
Remarks: This indicator captures the links ecosystems and biodiversity to wellness and mental health as well as the issues of equity embedded in access to these services. This indicator also explicitly engages with Indigenous Knowledge. Supplementary reporting units coudl include % of people participating in biodiversity-based recreation; % of people participating in biodiversity-based education; % of Indigeneous Peoples and local communities using traditional knowledge, Indigeneous Knowledge or local knowledge in adaptation.

Indicator name: Area under restoration for enhancing ecosystem resilience and services
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
(1) by ecosystem type: terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems, and all other relevant ecosystems as applicable
(2) by restoration status: initiated, in progress, or fully functional
Corresponding sub-target / component:
management, enhancement, restoration and conservation and the protection of terrestrial,
inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the area of degraded terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems restored to enhance resilience and the availability of ecosystem services. Restoration is defined to include: (a) restoring converted areas back to natural states; (b) improving the ecological integrity of degraded natural areas; and (c) rehabilitating converted and degraded areas (e.g. degraded agricultural lands) to improve both productivity and integrity.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Healthy, restored ecosystems regulate water flows, stabilize soils, buffer climate hazards, and support biodiversity, thereby sustaining climate-resilient livelihoods and food systems. The indicator is globally applicable as restoration in all contexts underpins ecosystem-based adaptation (EbA) and nature-based solutions (NbS). It reduces vulnerability and enhances resilience.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Based on CBD GBF Indicator 2.2 (area under restoration). SEEA Ecosystem Accounting provides standards for spatially explicit measurement and for linking restored area to ecosystem service flows. Metadata should be slightly adjusted to focus only on restoration activities with documented climate resilience outcomes (e.g., mangrove restoration reducing flood risk). https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/2-2
Data availability\n(Description): Geospatial monitoring of restoration areas is increasingly available through remote sensing and national reporting to CBD. The FAO is actively supporting the development of the indicator and the collection of national level data. However, reporting varies widely across countries. Stronger data exist for terrestrial and forest ecosystems, while inland water, coastal, and marine restoration are less consistently tracked. Developing countries, including LDCs and SIDS have data and monitoring gaps.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Countries report restoration areas using national inventories, SEEA Ecosystem Accounting and geospatial monitoring, verifying the area and its status (initiated, in progress, or functional) against agreed-upon criteria, and supplementary linking area restored to ecosystem service flows such as flood risk reduction, erosion control, and food and water security. Data can be aggregated regionally and globally with technical, technological, and financial support from international organizations such as CBD secretariat, UNEP, UNSD, and UNFCCC.
Remarks: This is a well-established CBD indicator and clearly adaptation-relevant. The main challenge is clarifying how to count restoration progress (initiated, in progress, or functional) and ensuring capacity for monitoring. Supplementary units could include % of degraded area restored.

Indicator name: Extent of ecosystems that contribute to climate resilience covered by protected areas and other effective area-based conservation measures
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
(1)  by ecosystem type: terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems, and all other relevant ecosystems as applicable
(2) by governance type: formally protected areas (PAs), other effective area-based conservation measures (OECMs), Indigenous, and community conserved areas.
(3) Coverage by effectiveness of management
(4) Coverage of key biodiversity areas (KBAs)
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent of terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine, and coastal ecosystems that contribute to climate resilience and that are under formal protection, conservation, and sustainable management, including protected areas (PAs) and other effective area-based conservation measures (OECMs). It is defined to measure the percentage area of these ecosystems covered by protected areas or OECMs
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Tracking the extent of ecosystems that are relevant for climate resilience are protected provides information on the role of conserved ecosystems in maintaining biodiversity, regulating climate, and providing ecosystem services that reduce vulnerability and enhance adaptive capacity. The indicator is globally applicable as it includes all ecosystems that are critical for climate resilience are conserved, sustainably managed, and equitably governed.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Based on CBD GBF Indicator 3.1 (coverage of protected areas and OECMs). Global metadata exists through the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) and the OECM database maintained by UNEP-WCMC and IUCN. Modifications in the metadata are needed on the apsects of biodiversity conseration that are linked to adaptation outcomes, such as reductions in the risks and impacts from climate-induced hazard and livelihood resilience.
See CBD metadata: https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/3-1
Data availability\n(Description): Data is available for spatial coverage and trends through global datasets such as WDPA, WD-OECM, and national CBD reports, with robust information by ecosystem type. Adaptation-relevant services within protected and conserved areas, such as flood regulation and food security support, are not systematically measured and are not currently integrated into conservation reporting in developing countries, particularly LDCs and SIDS.
Units: % of total area (terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine, and coastal ecosystems) under protection and sustainable management
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Many countries provide information to the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) and the World Database on Other Effective Area-Based Conservation Measures (WD-OECM) and integrate these with SEEA Ecosystem Accounting to link conservation with adaptation outcomes. Technological and methodological improvements are needed to improve reporting and to faciliate the identification of ecosystems particularly important for climate change resilience. Several internationl organisations are actively working on these isseus and provide support to countries, including UNEP-WCMC and IUCN, among others.
Remarks: This indicator is immediately operational through existing CBD monitoring systems. Its refinement for the GGA lies in explicitly linking conservation outcomes to adaptation benefits, ensuring it reflects both biodiversity and resilience gains. Supplementary units could include: hectares (ha), km², % of ecosystem extent under conservation.

Indicator name: Ecosystem resilience under climate change (measured by the Bioclimatic Ecosystem Resilience Index, BERI)
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
(1)  by ecosystem type: terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine and coastal ecosystems, and all other relevant ecosystems as applicable
(2) By geography: local, national, regional, global.
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The Bioclimatic Ecosystem Resilience Index (BERI) quantifies an ecosystem's capacity to adapt to climate change. In simple terms, it measures how well-connected an area's habitats are to future "climate-safe zones" for the species currently living there. To do this, the index combines on a spatial grid the current condition of the ecosystem with models that predict species shifts due to climate change. The result for each grid cell is a resilience value representing the amount of connected, safe habitat available in the future. The aggregate value for a larger area, such as a country, is then the average of all cell values within its territory, providing a holistic assessment of landscape resilience.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: The capacity of ecosystems and its link to biodiversity under climate impacts is key to understanding an ecosystem's adaptive capacity. By assessing how well ecosystems can accommodate climate-induced shifts in species distribution by analyzing the connectivity of natural habitats, this indicator informs conservation and management decisions. It can track changes over time that result from specific adaptation measures, such as habitat restoration or the creation of ecological corridors.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 10d MEL
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
The methodology and metadata for the Bioclimatic Ecosystem Resilience Index (BERI) have been developed by and are available from CSIRO (Australia's national science agency) and through scientific publications. The metadata is technical, detailing a model that integrates current ecosystem integrity with projections of climate-driven species shifts.
See:
Bioclimatic Ecosystem Resilience Index (BERI): https://gbf-indicators.org/metadata/other/8-4-C
Data availability\n(Description): Data and methods can be found: https://gbf-indicators.org/metadata/other/8-4-C
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The indicator is ready to be used. The methodology is developed. Global and national level data is available through CSIRO. Disagregated national data to focus on ecosystems particularly important for climate change adaptation and resilience may still be needed.
Remarks: The Bioclimatic Ecosystem Resilience Index (BERI) is a sophisticated indicator designed to measure an ecosystem's capacity to maintain its characteristic biodiversity in a changing climate, as it assesses an ecosystem's inherent resilience. This indicator was presented in two different submissions during the consultation process. The name “Bioclimatic ecosystem resilience index” should not be taken to imply that the indicator is produced as a composite indicator of a number of disparate metrics (in the same way that, e.g. the Multidimensional Poverty Index is compiled).

Indicator name: Threat status of ecosystems relevant for climate adaptation (Red List of Ecosystems)
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
(1) By realm, biome and ecosystem functional group (Global Ecosystem Typology levels 2 and 3 or equivalent)
(2) By Indigenous and traditional territories
(3) By protected areas or other effective area-based conservation measures
(4) By drivers of biodiversity loss (matched to the International Union for Conservation of Nature Threats).
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
The ‘Red List Index of Ecosystems (RLE)’ measures the average risk of ecosystem collapse across a group of ecosystems. It tracks genuine changes in risk status over time, excluding any changes that are due to improved knowledge or better data.
The index ranges from 0 to 1. A value of 1 means all ecosystems are in the 'Least Concern' category, while a value of 0 means all ecosystems have collapsed. Decreases in the index (towards 0) indicate a heightened risk, while increases (towards 1) show an improvement in ecosystem status.
It can be calculated for any set of ecosystem types at the subnational, national, regional, or global level. The proposed modification is to use this index to track changes resulting from adaptation measures and to disaggregate the data to specifically monitor the trends of ecosystems most vulnerable to climate change.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Ecosystems are threatened by climate change and also offer powerful solutions through appropriately designed conservation and restoration measures, such as Ecosystem-based Adaptation and Nature-based Solutions. The threat status of ecosystems provides critical information on both how they are being affected by climate change and the impacts (positive or negative) of response measures. This indicator is directly relevant for tracking progress on reducing climate impacts and protecting all major ecosystem types. It complements the "Extent of natural ecosystems" indicator by adding a crucial layer of information on their condition and viability. As a high-level "umbrella" indicator, it synthesizes threats across diverse ecosystems into a comprehensive assessment of overall risk. Its value is reinforced by its role as a core component for assessing Goal A of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, ensuring strong alignment with global biodiversity goals.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 10d MEL
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
This indicator is a core component for assessing Goal A of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, adopted through decision 15/5. It provides the foundational data on ecosystem risk. Its metadata was welcomed in decision 16/31.

The relevant methodological guidance can be found in the official CBD documentation:
CBD document CBD/COP/16/INF/3/Rev.1: https://www.cbd.int/doc/c/ea34/8414/8c5e6797d291af15f33d6e40/cop-16-inf-03-rev1-en.pdf.
Data availability\n(Description): Over 4,000 ecosystems have been assessed using the Red List of Ecosystems framework in over 110 countries (Nicholson et al. 2024). For Parties where assessments are not available, global terrestrial assessments are anticipated to be available for key ecosystems by 2026-2027, in particular key terrestrial and freshwater ecosystem types, with anticipated updates every 5 years. Some Parties have already undertaken repeat assessments (e.g. South Africa, Norway, and Finland) providing time-series. At a national level, the release will vary by Party. The RLE can already be calculated for all countries that have completed Red List of Ecosystems assessments and a time-series for those countries with repeat assessments. Countries can use available code or seek assistance to calculate RLE values from their National Red List of Ecosystems assessments.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The indicator is ready to be used. The methodology is developed.  Disagregated national data to focus on ecosystems particularly important for climate change adapation and resilience may still be needed. The operationzation of the indicator is being supported by IUCN.
Remarks: The RLE functions as a high-level "umbrella" indicator. It synthesizes complex information on threats to specific ecosystem types into a clear, comprehensive assessment of overall risk. It complements the "Extent of natural ecosystems" indicator by adding a critical layer of information on ecosystem condition and viability. The selection of this indicator is reinforced by its role as a core component for assessing Goal A of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, ensuring its alignment with global biodiversity goals.

Indicator name: Threat status of species relevant for climate adaptation (Red list index)
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
(1) By realm, biome and ecosystem functional group (Global Ecosystem Typology levels 2 and 3 or equivalent)
(2) By taxonomic group
(3) By drivers (matched to the International Union for (matched to the International Union for Conservation of Nature Threats)
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The global “Red List Index” measures change in aggregate extinction risk across groups of species. It is compiled from data on genuine changes over time in the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species category for each species, excluding any changes driven by improved knowledge or revised taxonomy. The Red List Index value ranges from 1 (meaning all species are categorized as ‘Least Concern’) to 0 (meaning all species are categorized as ‘Extinct’), and so indicates how far the set of species has moved overall towards extinction. It allows for comparisons between sets of species in both their overall level of extinction risk and in the rate at which this risk changes over time. This  captures the number of species protected or supported through adaptation-related conservation measures aimed at enhancing ecosystem resilience.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: As a fundamental component of biodiversity, the threat status of species provides a direct measure of the pressures they face. The Red List Index (RLI) can be disaggregated to specifically analyze the impacts of climate change. A decline in the index for climate-vulnerable species provides a clear, evidence-based signal of escalating climate impacts, while a stable or improving trend demonstrates the success of adaptation measures, such as habitat restoration or species management programs. An upward trend in the RLI signifies that the rate of biodiversity loss is decreasing, indicating that adaptation and conservation measures are proving effective. A downward trend means the extinction risk is worsening. RLI provides direct feedback on the effectiveness of policies and actions and can assess progress towards the target of reducing climate impacts on biodiversity. It is headline indicator A.1 of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework and an established indicator for SDG Target 15.5.1.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
This is headline indicator A.1 of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, adopted through decision 15/5. Its metadata was welcomed in decision 16/31.
See: https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/A-1 and CBD document CBD/COP/16/INF/3/Rev.1: https://www.cbd.int/doc/c/ea34/8414/8c5e6797d291af15f33d6e40/cop-16-inf-03-rev1-en.pdf.
The metadata would need to be modified slightly to include guidance on disaggregation for species relevant to adaptation.
Data availability\n(Description): Data is available through the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator:
The indicator is ready to be used. The methodology is developed and data is available. Disaggregated national data to focus on species particularly important for climate adaptation and resilience may still be needed. The operationalisation of the indicator is being supported by IUCN.
The thematic subset focused on species relevant for climate adaptation must be based on clear criteria, such as a species' role in ecosystem resilience (e.g., corals, pollinators), community protection (e.g., mangrove trees for coastal defense), or food security (e.g., key fish stocks or crop wild relatives).
Remarks: The disaggregated Red List Index for a country measures the aggregate extinction risk of its species, relative to that Party's potential contribution to global species survival. It is measured on a scale of 0 to 1, where 1 represents the maximum contribution to global survival (all species are 'Least Concern') and 0 represents the minimum contribution (all species are 'Extinct'). The “Red List Index” should not be taken to imply that it is a composite indicator of disparate metrics (like the Multidimensional Poverty Index). It is an integrated measure of extinction risk.

Indicator name: Extent of natural ecosystems relevant for climate adaptation
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
(1) By realm, biome and ecosystem functional group (Global Ecosystem Typology levels 2 and 3 or equivalent)
(2) By Indigenous and traditional territories 
(3) By natural and seminatural ecosystem
(4) By geography: local, national, regional, global.
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
The indicator is defined as the extent of natural and semi-natural ecosystems as a proportion of total area of the country at a particular point in time, expressed as a percentage. The point in time is the closing date of the accounting period for which the ecosystem accounts were compiled. Trends over time will be evident from changes in the proportion of total area over successive accounting periods.
The total surface area of a country includes land, inland water and, if applicable, territorial waters (i.e. ocean area in the exclusive economic zone). For countries with marine territory, the indicator should be compiled for the total surface area of the country, including territorial waters.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Healthy ecosystems are fundamental components of biodiversity and are critically affected by climate change. Their degradation and loss adversely affects biodiversity, exacerbates climate change, and undermines adaptive capacity. The conservation and restoration of ecosystems are essential strategies for adapting to the effects of climate change. By tracking progress on reducing climate impacts on ecosystems and biodiversity and protecting terrestrial, inland water, mountain, marine, and coastal ecosystems, it complements the "Red List of Ecosystems" indicator (9d07). The indicator is designed at a high level to capture changes across multiple ecosystem types, ensuring its global relevance. This is aligned with indicator 1.1 of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (decision 15/5), and its metadata was welcomed in decision 16/31.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
This indicator corresponds to headline indicator 1.1 of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, adopted through decision 15/5. Its metadata was welcomed in decision 16/31.
See: https://www.gbf-indicators.org/metadata/headline/1-1 and CBD document CBD/COP/16/INF/3/Rev.1: https://www.cbd.int/doc/c/ea34/8414/8c5e6797d291af15f33d6e40/cop-16-inf-03-rev1-en.pdf.
Data availability\n(Description): Many Parties have information on ecosystem extent. Further the Global Ecosystems Atlas, a collaborative initiative led by The Group on Earth Observations (GEO), is under active development to create a single, open, and trusted resource mapping the world's ecosystems to support global conservation, sustainable management, and restoration efforts. It provides harmonized geospatial data on the distribution, extent, and condition of global ecosystems to inform decision-making for governments, businesses, and communities.
Units:
For extent, percent (%)
The measurement unit for this indicator is the spatial extent (hectares or km2) expressed as the proportion (percentage or %) of extent of natural ecosystems relevant for climate adaptation over total extent
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The indicator is ready to be used. The methodology is developed, and the Global Ecosystem Atlas is creating an open-source data platform. The main operational step will be to disaggregate national data to focus on ecosystems most relevant to climate change adaptation and resilience.
Remarks: Disaggregated data to identify and prioritize those ecosystems that deliver climate adaptation benefits is needed. This indicator complements condition-based indicators like the Red List of Ecosystems.

Indicator name: Number of Parties reporting on adaptive capacity, resilience, and vulnerability reduction outcomes from EbA and NbS action in their NAPs, NDCs or other policies or programs
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
By outcome focus: a) Adaptive capacity, b) Resilience, c) Vulnerability reduction.
By approach: a) Ecosystem-based Adaptation (EbA), b) Nature-based Solutions (NbS).
By demographic group: Social categories (e.g., gender, Indigenous Peoples, local communities, vulnerable groups).
By sector: e.g., Water & sanitation, Infrastructure & human settlements, etc.
By geography: National, subnational, specific ecosystem type (e.g., coastal, forest).
By implementation stage: a) Scale (e.g., local, regional), b) Maturity (e.g., pilot, established).
Corresponding sub-target / component: reducing climate impacts on ecosystems and biodiversity; accelerating the use of ecosystem-based adaptation and nature-based solutions
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator provides a comprehensive assessment of global progress on outcomes of Ecosystem-based Adaptation (EbA) and Nature-based Solutions (NbS). It tracks the adoption of these approaches and their scale, maturity, and reported effectiveness in delivering key adaptation outcomes. This indicator aims to shift the focus from policy to tangible action and impact.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator measures the translation of global ambition into national policy and supplements the relevant indicators in target 10 by measuring planning exercises to assess real-world progress. It provides a direct line of sight between national actions and the achievement of the global goal, capturing the critical contribution of nature to enhancing adaptive capacity, strengthening resilience, and reducing vulnerability . The indicator provides a clear measure of tangible progress by revealing whether commitments are translating into concrete actions that deliver the key adaptation outcomes.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10b Planning, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Specific metadata for this new indicator needs to be developed. Its methodology can be grounded in well-established sources drawing from UNFCCC reporting guidelines, the IUCN Global Standard for Nature-based Solutions, and monitoring approaches from the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework.
Data availability\n(Description): Information on this indicator could be compiled for NAPs and other documentation, including monitoring, evaluation and learning, of EbA and NbS efforts. The primary data sources are official national documents submitted to the UNFCCC, including National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), National Communications and Biennial Transparency Reports (BTR).
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Each Party needs to identify its nature-based adaptation actions, categorize each one by its scale and maturity, assess their outcomes, and provide this information its official reports. Clear and practical definitions for the "scale" and "maturity" categories of implementation, as well as to guide how Parties can report on adaptation outcomes, both qualitatively and quantitatively are needed.
Remarks: The data of the outcomes could be further collected and compiled to track progress on these elements.

Indicator ID: 9(e) Increasing the resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts to ensure basic and continuous essential services for all, and minimizing climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements

Indicator name: Proportion of informal settlement upgrading programes that (i) include climate change adaptation and (ii) are locally led and co-designed
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Geographic, Climate-related hazards, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by geographic coverage, scope of adaptation measures (type—grey/engineered, green/ecosystem-based, soft/policy, financial; hazard—heat, flood, drought, wildfire, sea-level rise/storm surge; sector/asset—housing, transport, water, energy, health, ICT; scale—household, community, city/region, national; approach—avoid/protect/accommodate/retreat; degree—incremental vs transformative);  stage of implementation, level of co-design, inclusivity of vulnerable and marginalised groups, and incorporation into long-term planning or policy frameworks
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, ensure basic and continuous essential services, minimize climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which adaptation actions are led and co-designed by local communities, particularly those most vulnerable. It highlights participation, empowerment, and equity in adaptation planning and implementation.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
With over a billion people living in informal settlements (and 3 billion anticipated by the middle of the century) it is critical to enhance the adaptive capacity of informal settlements given their level of vulnerability and exposure.  Locally led and co-designed informal settlement upgrading programmes that integrate climate change adaptation address both development deficits and climate risk, ensuring that adaptation interventions are context-appropriate, equitable, and sustainable.  Upgrading progammes could be upcaked in metadata and include healthcare, land tenure as a minimum. 

Consistent with Paris Art.7 emphasis on vulnerable populations and Locally Led Adaptation principles (GCA/UN-Habitat).
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 10b Planning, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Not available
Data availability\n(Description): Municipal and national reports on upgrading initiatives; Existing UN-Habitat databases (e.g. Participatory Slum Upgrading Programme, Cities and Climate Change Initiative); project documentation from NGOs and development agencies; and SDG 11.1.1 / Voluntary Local Reviews referencing climate-responsive upgrading.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (6) Public participation, (2) Institutional arrangements, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance, (3) Policies
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Track number/coverage of settlement upgrading projects with climate criteria; compare to total informal settlements (UN-Habitat baseline)

Indicator name: Number of Parties that incorporate transboundary climate risks and adaptation measures for connected infrastructure and settlement systems in their National Adaptation Plans or equivalent documents
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Climate-related hazards, Any other, Economic sectors
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disagregation by adaptation / resilient infrastructure typology (e.g. water, electricity, telecommunications, critical transport routes, human mobility routes etc.)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, minimize climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which countries recognise and address transboundary climate risks that affect shared or connected infrastructure and settlement systems (e.g. transport corridors, river basins, energy grids, cross-border urban systems). It captures whether such considerations are integrated into formal adaptation planning and reporting processes, such as National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), or equivalent national reporting documents.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Supports inter-regional climate resilience, encourages cooperative governance, and aligns with calls under the Paris Agreement and Global Goal on Adaptation for integrated, systemic, and anticipatory adaptation approaches. 

Addresses transboundary climate risks highlighted by IPCC AR6 (shared rivers, coasts, supply chains, migration) that can undermine national adaptation gains.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: There are few metadata standards globally, however some existing ones such as UNECE, river basin commissions could be modified
Data availability\n(Description): National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), National Communications, complementary sources include regional/transboundary progress reports(e.g., SADC, ECOWAS), which often document cooperative infrastructure and settlement resilience measures that span national borders.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Inventory agreements/protocols addressing transboundary climate risk; classify by sector (water, transport, energy)

Indicator name: Number of Parties that include coverage of (i) critical thresholds, (ii) tipping points, and (iii) adaptation limits in National Adapation Plans and national risk assessments
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Climate-related hazards, Social categories, Geographic, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By element (AMOC, monsoon shifts, ice-sheet instabilities, permafrost carbon, Amazon/boreal/coral die-back); threshold type (biophysical, infrastructure, socio-economic, legal/policy)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, minimize climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the number of Parties that consider cirtical threshholds, tipping points and limits to adaptation in their planning. This can include NAPs but also other risk assessment or reporting documents.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Monitoring environmental, social and economic tipping points enhances preparedness, guides preventive action, and supports international collaboration on issues such as Amazon rainforest loss, Greenland ice melt, or collapse of coral reefs. 

Complements mitigation (but does not measure it) by preparing for overshoot-adjacent abrupt changes flagged in IPCC AR6 (e.g., ice sheets, AMOC, ecosystem dieback), signalling hard and soft limits to adaptation in some contexts.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9g Cultural heritage, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 10b Planning, 10c Implementation, 10d MEL
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: UNFCCC NAP Central metadata
Data availability\n(Description): Not widely reported as yet, data not well established but UNFCCC NAP Central is a source
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Text search and review of NAPs/NDCs for tipping points etc; record binary (yes/no) and type of tipping element referenced

Indicator name: Number of planned relocation protocols for human settlements and infrastructural system to facilitate inclusive and adequately supported and managed local-scale relocation
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Geographic, Climate-related hazards, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Could disagregate by reason (climate hazard), location, number of people, number of children etc.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, ensure basic and continuous essential services, minimize climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator assesses the presence and quality of planned and proactive relocation protocols for human settlements at risk of climate impacts (e.g. sea-level rise, flooding). It considers whether guidelines exist to ensure relocation is safe, inclusive, and rights-based.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Adaptation element(s): Decreases vulnerability (rights-based protection of livelihoods/services); reduces exposure where risks become intolerable; builds adaptive capacity via clear institutional roles and finance.

Global Goal linkage: Recognised in IPCC AR6 as an adaptation pathway when in-situ options are exhausted; aligns with Paris Art.7 focus on protecting people and systems.

I&HS relevance: Protocols enable anticipatory, not reactive, moves tied to risk thresholds, minimising disruption to water, health, education, energy
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Some countries/regions have developed plans based on their own needs, could be reviewed to develop indicator metadata
Data availability\n(Description): Potential sources include national and local disaster risk management strategies, climate change adaptation plans, and relocation/resettlement frameworks; UNHCR and IOM databases on planned relocation; and reporting under NAPs, NDCs, and Sendai Framework monitoring
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (1) Leadership, (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (6) Public participation, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance, (8) Others
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Record existence of planned relocation frameworks/protocols; count affected population; cross-check with IOM/UNHCR databases.

Indicator name: Number of Parties with national adaptation plans that integrate (i) nature based solutions (NbS) and (ii) ecosystem based adaptation (EbA) measures (green/ blue infrastructure) to manage and reduce climate change impacts in human settlements and infrastructure systems, with (i) identified actions, (ii) targets, and (iii) resource allocations
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, ensure basic and continuous essential services, minimize climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which NbS and EbA contribute to enhancing adaptive capacity and increasing mitigation potential in human settlements and infrastructure systems. It highlights synergies between adaptaion and mitigation.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Nature-based solutions and EbA are consistently highlighted in IPCC AR6 WGII, UNEP Adaptation Gap Report, and the Global Commission on Adaptation as among the most cost-effective, multi-benefit approaches to adaptation. They reduce physical risks (floods, heat, coastal erosion), while also enhancing biodiversity, carbon sequestration, and human well-being.

Acts as a signal for global progress: if NbS/EbA integration remains rhetorical or underfunded, it suggests systemic risk and missed opportunities for transformative adaptation.

Relevance to I&HS: NbS/EbA directly support resilient infrastructure and settlements — e.g., wetlands for urban flood control, mangroves for coastal protection, green corridors for cooling, and blue infrastructure for drainage.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9f Poverty & livelihoods
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: IUCN Global Standard for NbS: This metadata refers to the application of the IUCN Global Standard for Nature‑based Solutions in urban contexts, enabling cities to design, assess, and scale NbS interventions through a structured framework of 8 criteria and 28 indicators. It supports self-assessment, benchmarking, and continuous improvement using tools like a traffic‑light scoring system to highlight best practice compliance. The standard was developed through extensive global consultation and includes guidance, a user-friendly tool, and governance mechanisms to ensure consistent and adaptive application across local, national, and global levels.
Data availability\n(Description): NAPs, NDCs, and National Communications under the UNFCCC; UN Environment Programme and UNFCCC NAP Central databases
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation, (1) Leadership, (8) Others
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Code national/local adaptation projects for EbA measures; aggregate as % of total IHS adaptation projects.
Remarks: Gap addressed: Many national adaptation plans (NAPs) mention NbS/EbA, but few translate them into actionable measures with budgets and targets. Without this, NbS/EbA risk being rhetorical rather than operational. Supports Paris Art.7 by advancing adaptation that is ecosystem-based, scalable, and context-specific, addressing the GGA call for resilience of natural and human systems.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have established relevant standards or taxonomies designed to align public and private sector finance for Infrastructure & Human Settlement adaptation
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Climate-related hazards, Any other, Economic sectors
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By Party; sectors (housing, transport, water, energy); note coverage of vulnerable groups if defined
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, ensure basic and continuous essential services
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator captures whether Parties have developed standards or taxonomies that categorise and guide financial flows in a way that aligns public and private sector investment towards adaptation in infrastructure and human settlements
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Global Goal linkage: Supports Paris Art.7 by clarifying what qualifies as adaptation, improving integrity and steering finance away from maladaptation (as flagged by IPCC AR6). This helps identify the proportion of financed infrastructure and human settlement projects that are climate-resilient by design, meaning they integrate climate risk assessments and adaptation measures into planning, construction, and operation phases.

I&HS relevance: Enables bankable, standards-aligned resilient infrastructure and upgrades; improves transparency and comparability across jurisdictions.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: EU Taxonomy for Sustainable Finance, Climate Bonds Taxonomy, ASEAN Taxonomy, metadata in finance frameworks
Data availability\n(Description): EU Taxonomy for Sustainable Finance, Climate Bonds Taxonomy, ASEAN Taxonomy, metadata in finance frameworks, MDB/DFI climate finance tracking; and initiatives such as CPI/CCFLA and UNEP-FI tracking private sector alignment with adaptation standards.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (4) Data & knowledge, (8) Others, (3) Policies
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Track existence of national/regional taxonomies including IHS criteria; review coverage of adaptation activities in finance taxonomies.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have national adaptation plans, policy instruments and/or strategies which include a consideration of the impact of temperature goal overshoot on the effectiveness of adaptation in relation to basic infrastructure
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By Party; split if overshoot measures address vulnerable groups (e.g. children, Indigenous, migrants, poor etc)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Increasing resilience of infrastructure and human settlements to climate change impacts, minimize climate-related impacts on infrastructure and human settlements
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures how many countries have National Adaptation Plans (NAPs), policy instruments and/or strategies that explicitly address the risks of overshooting global temperature goals (e.g. exceeding 1.5°C or 2°C). It captures whether adaptation planning considers higher warming scenarios, not just the Paris Agreement targets.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Critical in view of impending temperature goal overshoot of 1.5C (and above)  which will test adaptation limits both through exceedance and the responses implemented to return to 1.5C. Including this dimension reflects a risk-aware governance approach and supports the GGA’s objective to reduce vulnerability under a wide range of plausible futures. It also aligns with Article 7 of the Paris Agreement, which emphasises the need for adaptation that is anticipatory, participatory, and based on the best available science. Global Goal connection: While emissions reduction is critical to hold warming to 1.5°C or well below 2°C, adaptation must also prepare for overshoot scenarios. Embedding overshoot (both exceedance and return) in NAPs ensures countries can meet adaptation requirements across a range of warming levels, and identifies signals of potential adaptation limits

Decision text reference: SB62 15(e)
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 10d MEL, 10b Planning, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Not available
Data availability\n(Description): UNFCCC NAP Central; no countries include overshoot scenarios in a standardised manner
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (1) Leadership
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Review NAPs and adaptation communications for explicit mention of overshoot/tipping points; code for inclusion/exclusion; aggregate globally.
Remarks:
Direct response to SB62 para 15(e).

Capacity of countries to adapt within their carbon budget should be considered

Indicator ID: 9(f) Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on poverty eradication and livelihoods, in particular by promoting the use of adaptive social protection measures for all

Indicator name: Proportion of population living in multidimensional poverty in areas highly exposed to climate-related hazards
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on poverty eradication
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the level of multidimensional poverty in areas exposed to different climate hazards over time. Multidimensional poverty is based on national definitions and refers to deprivation in multiple aspects of well-being beyond income, such as education, health, housing, and access to basic services.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Reducing multidimensional poverty in areas exposed to climate-related hazards strengthens the adaptive capacity of vulnerable populations (beyond the monetary dimension) by improving their access to resources, services, and opportunities essential for coping with and adapting to climate-related impacts. Rising multidimensional poverty in areas exposed to climate-related hazards points to insufficient or ineffective adaptation.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: SDG 1.2.2 metadata but adding methodology to identify areas exposed to climate-related hazards needs development. Hazards should include droughts, floods, storms, heat and others of national relevance.
Data availability\n(Description): Data on multidimensional poverty is available for 87 Parties. Specific data on poverty rates in areas exposed to climate-related hazards is not yet available. Custodians: World Bank, UNICEF and UNDP
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Data is mostly available. Operationalisation will require the development of methodology for identifying areas exposed to different climate-related hazards. Parties may select those hazards that are the most relevant for them. Parties may require capacity development.
Remarks: An alternative methodology that could be leveraged for this indicator and which also captures the link between exposure and vulnerability is the World Bank's ScoreCard vision indicator of proportion of people at high risk from climate-related hazards. Metadata for this indicator is available, along with data for over 100 Parties.

Indicator name: Proportion of population living below the international poverty line in areas highly exposed to climate-related hazards
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on poverty eradication
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the eradication of extreme poverty in areas exposed to climate-related hazards, measured through the international poverty line which are standardized monetary income or consumption thresholds, adjusted for differences in price levels.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Monetary poverty is both a driver of vulnerability and low adaptive capacities as well as an outcome of insufficient adaptation. International poverty lines are relevant to track global adaptation progress for extreme poverty eradication.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: SDG 1.1.1 metadata but adding methodology to identify areas exposed to climate-related hazards needs development. Hazards should include droughts, floods, storms, heat and others of national relevance.
Data availability\n(Description): Data on poverty rates using the international poverty line is available for over 160 Parties. Specific data on poverty rates in areas exposed to climate-related hazards is not yet available. Custodian: World Bank
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Data is mostly available. Operationalisation will require the development of methodology for identifying areas exposed to different climate-related hazards. Parties may select those hazards that are the most relevant for them. Parties may require capacity development.

Indicator name: Proportion of population living below the national poverty line in areas highly exposed to climate-related hazards
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on poverty eradication
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the eradication of poverty according to national definitions in areas exposed to different climate-related hazards. The national poverty rate is the percentage of the total population living below the national poverty line set by the Party.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Monetary poverty is both a driver of vulnerability and low adaptive capacities as well as an outcome of insufficient adaptation. National poverty lines are important to track national progress towards reducing the impact of climate change on poverty eradication, according to national circumstances and definitions.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9g Cultural heritage
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: SDG 1.2.1 metadata but adding methodology to identify areas exposed to climate-related hazards needs development. Hazards should include droughts, floods, storms, heat and others of national relevance.
Data availability\n(Description): Data on poverty rates according to national poverty lines is available for over 150 Parties, spanning over 30 years. Specific data on poverty rates in areas exposed to climate-related hazards is not yet available. Custodian: World Bank
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Data is mostly available. Operationalisation will require the development of methodology for identifying areas exposed to different climate-related hazards. Parties may select those hazards that are the most relevant for them. Parties may require capacity development.

Indicator name: Proportion of workers in climate-vulnerable economic sectors/activities (following ISIC classification)
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Formality (formal/informal)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on livelihoods
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator establishes how concentrated the workforce and thus people's livelihoods and incomes are in economic sectors that are highly sensitive to climate change. Disaggregations including by formality, are essential to establish the vulnerability of the workforce within climate-sensitive sectors. A workforce with a large proportion of informal workers in highly climate-sensitive sectors is highly vulnerable to climate change. Sector classifications should follow the International Standard Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities (ISIC).
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Diversifying the workforce, supporting workers’ transition away from climate-sensitive economic activities, and reducing informality in climate-sensitive sectors (including in agriculture) is essential for climate change adaptation. This indicator measures long-term economic resilience of Parties. The lower the reliance/concentration of livelihoods on a small number of informal climate-sensitive economic activities, the lower the risk of income loss and poverty when climate shocks occur.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Standardized methodology to be developed for identifying thresholds for climate-vulnerable sectors.
Data availability\n(Description): Distribution of employment by sector and activity is readily available from ILOSTAT for all Parties, based on labour force surveys. Custodianship of the indicator to be established.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Data on the distribution of workers across economic sectors/activities and across formal and informal economy is readily available from labour force surveys. Operationalization will mostly require the development of a standardised methodology for determining climate-vulnerable economic sectors (with thresholds) for application across Parties.

Indicator name: Proportion of enterprises adopting climate change adaptation measures
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Size (number of workers) and formality (formal/informal)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on livelihoods
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Enterprises include all forms of businesses from micro-, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) to large corporations that contribute to economic growth, livelihoods and job creation. Enterprises also include cooperatives, producer enterprises and other social and solidarity entities. Enterprises can be both formal or informal. Relevant adaptation measures should be defined during methodology development.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator reflects the private sector’s adaptive capacity to reduce climate-related risks to production, employment, and supply chains. Strong enterprise adaptation helps protect livelihoods, maintain economic stability, and strengthen community resilience in the face of climate impacts. The private sector provides between 75% and 90% of jobs worldwide, hence the adaptation and resilience of enterprises is vital to reduce the adverse impacts of climate change on livelihoods.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: To be developed, including definitions for climate change adaptation measures and data sources to ensure all types and sizes of enterprises are covered.
Data availability\n(Description): Formal sector enterprise surveys are available from over 150 Prties but they currently include very limited to no information on climate change adaptation. Informal sector enterprise survey are available for a much more limited number of Parties. Some Labour Force Surveys include informal sector modules. Custodianship to be established.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata and methodology need to be developed; Parties require capacity building for collecting data required for the indicator. Establishing a custodian agency could to help standardise data collection, data quality control and data analysis.

Indicator name: Proportion of the adult population in climate-sensitive economic sectors with access to formal credit
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Geographic, Any other
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on livelihoods
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks access to finance (formal credit), especially for those working in climate-sensitive sectors. Access to credit can be established by reporting on the number of borrowers per 100,000 people (supply-side) or by reporting the proportion of the adult population having borrowed from a regulated institution in the previous 12 months (demand-side)
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Access to finance, measured through access to formal credit enables individuals, households and businesses make necessary investments for adaptation. Access to credit can also support the recovery following climate-related shocks and can increase productivity and thus adaptive capacity. Many workers and small businesses, especially those in rural areas face barriers to accessing credit, making adaptation challenging and undermining resilience. Credit markers must be made more inclusive and accessible for those currently excluded who are often among those most vulnerable to climate change. This indicator will help track progress towards this goal.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata needs some modification to integrate climate-relevant disaggregations (e.g., by climate sensitive sectors) but can be based on IMF FAS metadata and/or Findex metadata.
Data availability\n(Description): Parties that don’t collect data to develop standard finanical inclusion indicators, including those linked to credit, can use the World Bank's Findex Survey, World Bank Group’s Enterprise Surveys, or IMF’s Financial Access Survey data, or can include questions from these surveys in their national surveys.  The Global Findex survey covers over 140 Parties and collects data every three years. Custodian: World Bank
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Dedicated metadata to be developed based on metadata from existing surveys. Data mostly available with low barriers to operationalization.

Indicator name: Proportion of population covered by climate risk insurance
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Type of insurance (agricultural / property / business continuity); insurance modality (indemnity-based / index-based) and risk-pooling (macro / meso / micro)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Substantially reducing the adverse effects of climate change on livelihoods
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the population covered by climate risk insurances, including agricultural insurances (e.g., crop, livestock), property, and business continuity insurance.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate risk insurances help people, households and enterprises manage the risks of climate-related hazards by transferring risk to the insurer, thereby enhancing resilience and enabling investments in adaptation. They can help replace productive assets, safeguard investments and ensure business continuity, which in turn protects the livelihoods of workers. While traditional indemnity-based insurances are often inaccessible or unaffordable in high-risk regions or informal settlements, parametric/index-based insurances and public-private risk pooling models can be tailored to low income contexts to extend protection to underserved populations.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9b Food & agricultural, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10c Implementation
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata and methodology to be developed. Methodology could be based on InsuResilience M&E Framework which already defines the methodology for a similar indicator.
Data availability\n(Description): No information on data availability but it is likely low. Custodianship to be established.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata and methodology need to be developed; Parties require capacity building for collecting data required for the indicator. Establishing a custodian agency could to help standardise data collection, data quality control and data analysis.

Indicator name: Proportion of population vulnerable to climate change covered by social protection systems
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Social categories, Economic sectors, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Sub-national unit (by exposure to climate-related hazards) and economic sector (climate-sensitive versus less climate-sensitive sectors)
Corresponding sub-target / component: Promoting the use of adaptive social protection measures for all
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks progress towards covering all people by social protection, especially those exposed and vulnerable to climate change impacts. Adaptive social protection for all means (1) people must be covered by social protection systems (9f08) and (2) social protection systems must be adapted to climate risks (9f09). Social protection systems include benefits for children, pregnant women with newborns, people in working age in case of unemployment or inusfficient income, older persons (pensions), for victims of work injuries and persons with disabilities. They also include social health protection.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Social protection systems address structural vulnerabilities and risks which are exacerbated by climate change (e.g., deprivation in childhood, old age, vulnerability of pregnant women, people with disabilities, income and job losses, general poverty risk) by providing income security/support and access to affordable healthcare.
