Evidence confirms  that extending social protection coverage reduces the impact of climate change on poverty eradication (Jafino et al. 2020) and that high coverage systems are better able to respond to climate shocks when they occur. Therefore, universal coverage of the full range of lifecycle risks is a fundamental indicator to measure resilience, adaptive capacity and reduced vulnerability. The proposed additional disaggregation levels are important for the adaptation relevance of the indicator.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: SDG 1.3.1 metadata to be modified to establish methodology for climate-specific enhancements of the indicator, e.g., social protection coverage among those in climate-sensitive economic sectors and social protection coverage in sub-national units exposed to different climate hazards.
Data availability\n(Description): Effective social protection coverage data is available for 214 Parties and territories. Sex disaggregation is available for approximately 25% of all Parties and territories. Disaggreagtion by climate-sensitive economic sector, climate exposed sub-national unit and migrant/refugee status, is not yet available. Custodian: ILO
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: General coverage data is readily available and reported. The operationalization of the climate-specific disaggregations will require further investments, both in terms of methodology development, data collection and capacity building of government agencies responsible for social protection statistics.
Remarks: These indicators are complementary to one another. Together, the two indicators provide information on availability of adaptive social protection measures for all which cannot be measured through a single indicator.

Indicator name: Level of social protection system preparedness/adaptiveness to respond to climate change impacts
Corresponding sub-target / component: Promoting the use of adaptive social protection measures for all
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Adapting social protection systems to climate risks allows them to be more resilient and responsive in the face of climate shocks, to ensure financial assistance reaches all those affected in a timely manner. It also allows them to better support livelihood transitions, diversification and adaptation by linking social protection schemes with green livelihood and employment programmes.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: To be developed, including the methodology and the selection of social protection systems dimensions to be assessed.
Data availability\n(Description): No data currently available. Data could eventually be collected through the ILO's Social Security Inquiry, the same data collection instrument that also collects data on social protection coverage (see above). The ILO directly collaborates with and builds the statistical capacity of government agencies responsible for social protection provision and statistics, including ministries of labour, finance, social development and other social protection institutions. It also holds agreements with other agencies to receive complementary information on social protection.
Units: Level (Quantitative score that may be combined with qualitative narrative)
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The methodology for the indicator will be developed based on existing evidence and tools for assessing social protection system preparedness/adaptiveness. Data could eventually be collected through the ILO's Social Security Inquiry, the same data collection instrument that also collects data on social protection coverage (see above). The ILO directly collaborates with and builds the statistical capacity of government agencies responsible for social protection provision and statistics, including ministries of labour, finance, social development and other social protection institutions. It also holds agreements with other agencies to receive complementary information on social protection.

Indicator ID: 9(g) Protecting cultural heritage from the impacts of climate-related risks by developing adaptive strategies for preserving cultural practices and heritage sites and by designing climate-resilient infrastructure, guided by traditional knowledge, Indigenous Peoples’ knowledge and local knowledge systems

Indicator name: Percentage of at-risk cultural and natural heritage sites with adaptation measures implemented
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Protecting cultural heritage from the impacts of climate related risks;
by developing adaptive strategies for preserving cultural practices and heritage sites
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator measures the level of implementation of adaptation measures on cultural and natural heritage sites identified as at risk.  This includes adaptation measures implemented for different types of cultural and natural heritage lists (international listed and listed by Parties - Parties have national, subnational, and local lists of classified/designated heritage sites) and non-listed sites. 
Cultural and natural heritage sites at risk from climate impacts are identified through national and subnational (local) or sectoral impacts, risk and vulnerability and other relevant assessments. 
Implemented measures include existing adaptive strategies that are supported through laws, regulations, or community support, as well as new adaptation measures implemented.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Cultural and natural heritage is increasingly exposed to climate change hazards and impacts, placing them increasingly at-risk of impacts that threaten their existence, their cultural values, and their continued access and use. Therefore, it is critical for cultural and natural heritage sites to be protected from increasing climate change impacts through the implementation of site specific adaptation measures and actions. Such adaptation measures may include new and innovative solutions using new technologies or simply ensuring support for the continuation of long-standing local adaptation measures that have enabled the heritage sites to be responsive to its geography and survive through generations. It is critical to include also non-listed sites as many of these are not documented or classified under formal systems. 
The IPCC AR6 assesses with medium confidence that "cultural losses, related to tangible and intangible heritage, may result in irrevocable losses of sense of belonging, valued cultural practices, identity and home, particularly for Indigenous Peoples."
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9b Food & agricultural, 9a Water & sanitation, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Documentation for non-listed heritage sites via multiple data sources and organisations. 
Metadata on cultural heritage is available from UNESCO Culture|2030 Indicators https://whc.unesco.org/en/culture2030indicators/
Internationally listed cultural heritage sites by UNESCO is found here: https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/  and Geoparks: https://www.unesco.org/en/iggp/geoparks/about

The Ramsar sites are found here: https://www.ramsar.org/document/list-wetlands-international-importance-ramsar-list         and https://whc.unesco.org/document/203725
Data availability\n(Description):
Lists of cultural and natural heritage sites is available with Parties at different levels of government. List of at-risk sites could be developed via NAPs or other national documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTR national communication, etc.), other sources where such assessments exist or can be undertaken such as IPCC, academic literature, grey literature eg implementation reports, other organisations and networks including heritage adaptation professionals networks; UNESCO, data is also available from whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/ and https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/  and https://www.unesco.org/en/iggp/geoparks/about
and https://www.ramsar.org/document/list-wetlands-international-importance-ramsar-list   and https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000394251
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (4) Data & knowledge, (2) Institutional arrangements, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Requires modification of existing metadata from UNESCO, Ramsar lists, etc to include other lists, such as from Parties (national, subnational and local level) and non-listed cultural and natural heritage sites that can be potentially sourced across multiple data sources. Metadata should include defining levels of implementation of adaptation measures, such as; early stage, medium, advanced stages, final stage or completed.

Indicator name: Percentage of intangible cultural heritage elements with enhanced resilience to climate change impacts
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
Disaggregated by intangible cultural heritage or living heritage
(i) internationally listed
(ii) listed or identified by Parties at national, subnational, or local levels.
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Protecting cultural heritage from the impacts of climate related risks;
by developing adaptive strategies for preserving cultural practices and heritage sites
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which adaptation measures and actions that are implemented have enhanced the resilience of communities to develop the capacity to adapt to climate related adversity to safeguard and continue practicing their intangible cultural heritage. Resilience can be developed through the support for laws, regulations and measures put in place by the state party at various levels of government or at an international level. Intangible cultural heritage elements, including practices and knowledges that continue to thrive demonstrate enhanced resilience in the face of climate change impacts.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator focuses on ensuring that intangible cultural heritage elements (festivals, ceremonies, oral traditions, practices, and knowledges etc.) continue to thrive in communities where they are most meaningful, demonstrating that adaptation have been successfully implemented in response to climate risks to ensure their resilience. It also provides a global picture of the extent to which intangible practices have been made more resilient through climate adaptation. Cultural practices are dynamic and often not included in formal inventories.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Documentation for non-listed heritage intangible cultural heritage via multiple data sources and organisations. 
Metadata on cultural heritage is available from UNESCO Culture|2030 Indicators https://whc.unesco.org/en/culture2030indicators/
Internationally listed intangible cultural heritage elements by UNESCO is found here: https://ich.unesco.org/en/
Data availability\n(Description):
https://whc.unesco.org/en/culture2030indicators/
Internationally listed intangible cultural heritage elements by UNESCO is found here: https://ich.unesco.org/en/  and whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/;  NAPs or other national documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTR national communication, etc.). Academic literature, NGO reports, and other sources can provide additional data, including diverse climate adaptation heritage professional networks outside of UN agencies
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (6) Public participation, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator:
Metadata should define "enhanced resilience" 
Like in 9g01; Requires modification of existing metadata from UNESCO, Ramsar, etc to include other lists, such as from Parties (national, subnational and local level) and non-listed cultural and natural heritage sites.
Remarks: Enhanced resilience needs to be clearly defined as part of standardizing the language for the indicator.

Indicator name: Proportion of cultural heritage protected from climate impacts by (i) digitizing for preservation and recovery, (ii) storing movable heritage in climate-resilient facilities
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by cultural and natural heritage listed in (i) international lists (ii) Parties lists at national, subnational, and local levels; cultural heritage includes sites, intangible cultural heritage elements/ practices, and moveable cultural heritage objects.
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The cultural heritage protected includes all forms of climate vulnerable tangible heritage (built, archaeological, movable, and underwater etc.), natural heritage, and intangible cultural heritage. Listed cultural heritage  includes listed (at international level, listed by Parties, national, subnational and local level lists). Parties have national, subnational, and local lists of classified/designated cultural heritage and other heritage that might not be listed. Specific focus on knowledge continuity of at-risk heritage collections; the indicator focuses on the  percentage of important cultural items that are in danger from climate change. This includes focus on use of technology to preserve cultural heritage as well as to document them in a form that supports recovery of cultural heritage that might be threatened by climate change impacts.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Use of new technologies to document and preserve cultural heritage is an important way to protect knowledge about them for future generations as well as for recovery and reconstruction of cultural heritage when affected by climate change impacts and hazards. Digitization of cultural heritage elements will ensure that in the event of climate -related hazards, such as floods, fire, at least documentation on them will be protected. Climate resilient structures are constructed to store the most valuable movable cultural heritage. Storing movable heritage in climate-resilient facilities protects cultural heritage from climate-related impacts including hazards as well as slow onset events.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Partial metadata on cultural and natural heritage lists available through international organizations and Parties lists at various level of government as well as private museums (for example UNESCO Culture Sector) https://whc.unesco.org/en/culture2030indicators/  and https://whc.unesco.org/en/ and 
Safeguarding Culture in Times of Crisis | UNESCO
Data availability\n(Description):
Data on cultural and natural heritage lists available through international organizations and Parties lists at various level of government as well as private museums (for example UNESCO Culture Sector) Data on digitazation is available through a variety of international organizations including the EU, UNESCO, CBD, UNEP, ICOM, IUCN etc. Data is needed on specifically climate vulnerable cultural heritage, both listed and non-listed.  https://whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/  ; and https://whc.unesco.org/en/;  and 
https://unesco.org/en/emergencies/culture/
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (4) Data & knowledge, (3) Policies, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance, (5) Skills & education
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata still needs to be developed, drawing upon multiple sources

Indicator name: Percentage of cultural heritage with emergency preparedness and response plans in place for climate change related hazards
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
Disaggregated by listed cultural heritage sites, intangible cultural heritage elements, cultural objects, and natural heritage included in 
(i) international lists,
(ii) listed by Parties at national, subnational, and local levels.
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Protecting cultural heritage from the impacts of climate related risks;
by developing adaptive strategies for preserving cultural practices and heritage sites
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the existence of emergency preparedness and response plans for those cultural heritage sites, objects and  elements/practices that are recognized, protected and safeguarded by the Parties (international, national, subnational, and local levels), and their  implementation. "In place" means that Parties have not only proposed such measures in the management and safeguarding plans, but that these "emergency preparedness and response plans" have also been implemented and operationalized to avert or minimize impacts in the event of a climate-related hazards. Thus, the indicator focuses on two things (i) developing emergency preparedness and response plans for relevant sites/practices; (ii) the proposed actions have been operationalized and preparedness measures as well as response readiness measures are in place. Parties could report on these two levels. Details to be included in the metadata.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate change related events and hazards, increasingly common in recent years, are having devastating impacts on cultural heritage sites and elements/practices. Having emergency preparedness and response plans focused on climate related hazards allows Parties to have a detailed procedure on preparedness measures to avert and minimize impacts and response measures for actions in case of climate change related hazards. This includes both slow onset and rapid onset events.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Metadata is partially available with UNESCO and with ICCROM.  https://whc.unesco.org/document/203725   and https://whc.unesco.org/en/ and 
Safeguarding Culture in Times of Crisis | UNESCO;
Data availability\n(Description): Some data is available with UNESCO for cultural and natural heritage sites (including World Heritage sites, Biosphere reserves, and Geoparks); as well as for intangible cultural heritage elements. https://www.unesco.org/en/links  and https://whc.unesco.org/en/  and https://ich.unesco.org/en/ and Safeguarding Culture in Times of Crisis | UNESCO and whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/; Under the UNFCCC Convention, data is potentially available through NAPs or other national documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTR national communication, etc.), other sources eg IPCC, academic literature, grey literature eg implementation reports
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (5) Skills & education, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata should define "in place" as this relates to the implementation of the plans (not just having developed them). Like in 9g01, levels of implementation of this plans can be added in the metadata for this indicator.

Indicator name: Percentage of climate change adaptation plans, policies and strategies that incorporate the safeguarding and protection of cultural heritage
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Plans as NAP, Regional Plans, Action Area Plans, National or subnational plan, policies or strategies; or city level adaptation plans;
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Protecting cultural heritage from the impacts of climate related risks;
by developing adaptive strategies for preserving cultural practices and heritage sites
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which adaptation plans, policies and strategies at national or subnational levels include adaptation measures for cultural heritage (tangible, intangible cultural heritage, and natural heritage) to reduce cultural heritage vulnerability to climate change as well as climate change impacts on cultural heritage.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: National, sub-national and local climate change adaptation plans, policies, and strategies, often exclude considerations of cultural heritage as a standalone sector compared to other sectors/themes such as agriculture, water, health, infrastructure, ecosystems. Therefore, this indicator aims to streamline and mobilize Parties to integrate considerations of cultural heritage and increase the prominence of cultural heritage in adaptation planning and implementation. This can increase the implementation of adaptation measures that protects and safeguard various forms of cultural heritage globally. It can give a global picture of cultural heritage integration to climate adaptation, with optimal value of all countries integrating cultural heritage into adaptation with focus on climate vulnerability
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata is from the UNFCCC documentation under the Convention
Data availability\n(Description):
Some data is available with UNESCO 
whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/ and from Parties from authorities responsible for developing adaptation plans at national, subnational, and local levels; NAPs or other national documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTR national communication, etc.), other sources eg IPCC, academic literature, grey literature eg implementation reports
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (3) Policies, (2) Institutional arrangements, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The metadata should define the key terms here in relation to adaptation for the sector: safeguarding and protection of cultural heritage

Indicator name: Number of relevant climate change adaptation training programmes that integrate cultural heritage and/or guidance from traditional, local or Indigenous knowledge
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the extent to which training and awareness raising regarding climate change adaptation integrates i) cultural heritage considerations where cultural heritage includes tangible, intangible, and natural heritage; ii)  adaptive strategies and practices guided by traditional, local, or Indigenous knowledge. This indicator also serves to address the MOI indicators regarding capacity building and access.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: A majority of training programmes and awareness raising initiatives regarding climate change adaptation, from the international to local levels, do not include considerations of cultural and natural heritage sites or of intangible heritage elements/practices. They neither include adaptive practices that are guided by traditional, local, or indigenous knowledge. Hence, this indicator aims to highlight and mobilize Parties to integrate cultural heritage considerations in all relevant training programmes at all levels as well as including adaptive practices guided by diverse knowledge systems including traditional, local, or Indigenous knowledge where applicable
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Metadata is partially available with UNESCO 
whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/
Data availability\n(Description): Some data is available with UNESCO for climate change adaptation programmes, sustainability integration/awareness, education and training curricula https://whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/ and https://www.unesco.org/en/links  and from Parties from training programmes organized through agencies, and programmes authorized to conduct such training using national, subnational, or local funds, or funds from multilater or bilateral donors. Under the UNFCCC Convention, such data is likely in NAPs or other national documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTRs, National Communications etc.), other sources include also IPCC, academic literature, grey literature and implementation reports. Data is likely found also in organisations that work directly on climate change adaptation such as NGOs, climate funds, research organisations, that either invest in or deliver such programs.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata still needs to be developed, drawing upon multiple sources

Indicator name: Percentage of cultural heritage specific climate adaptation measures that engage with and are informed by local or Indigenous Peoples and their knowledge systems
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by (i) measures informed/ guided by traditional, local, or indigenous knowledge; ii) measures developed with the participation of local communities or Indigenous Peoples.
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Protecting cultural heritage from the impacts of climate related risks by developing adaptive strategies for preserving cultural practices and heritage sites;
Guided by traditional knowledge, Indigenous People's knowledge and local knowledge systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator measures the extent to which climate change adaptation strategies for cultural and natural heritage i) engage the participation of local communities or Indigenous Peoples; ii) are informed by local, traditional, or Indigenous knowledge
Hence this indicator aims to measure climate change adaptation measures specific to cultural or natural  heritage that are guided/informed by local, traditional, or Indigenous knowledge systems as well as those that have engaged the participation of local communities and Indigenous Peoples.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Climate adaptation measures for cultural heritage would benefit from an increasing engagement with diverse knowledge systems and stakeholder groups (traditional, local or Indigenous) that can strengthen adaptation of all types of cultural heritage. The IPCC AR6 SYR found with high confidence that "meaningful participation and inclusive planning, informed by cultural values, Indigenous Knowledge, local knowledge, and scientific knowledge can help address adaptation gaps and avoid maladaptation".
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 9f Poverty & livelihoods
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata for this indicator needs to be developed.
Data availability\n(Description):
Data on adaptation measures that engage Indigenous peoples has been assessed in IPCC (AR5, AR6 and will be in AR7). Similarly, information and data sources under the UNFCCC such as NAPs or other national climate change documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTRs, NDCs etc.), other sources such as academic literature, grey literature eg implementation reports. 
Some data on adaptation measures that engage with local or Indigenous Peoples and their knowledge systems are available at UNESCO: Dive into intangible cultural heritage! and https://ich.unesco.org/en/ and https://www.unesco.org/en/links  and https://whc.unesco.org/en  and https://whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (6) Public participation, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata should clearly define/explain "engage with" as this relates to the level of participation of local communities and/or Indigenous Peoples in the implementation of adaptation measures/ actions. Levels of participation should be defined in the metadata for this indicator to go beyond just informing the process.

Indicator name: Number of cultural heritage buildings and sites retrofitted with climate-resilient materials and/or technologies, including those guided by traditional, local, or Indigenous building practices
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
Disaggregated by retrofitted with climate resilient
(i) materials or
(ii) technologies or
(iii) guided by traditional, local, or Indigenous building practices
(iv) New construction that integrates adaptive practices guided by traditional, local, or Indigenous building practices
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator focuses specifically on climate adaptation of historic buildings and sites that are vulnerable to climate change impacts and hazards. It includes retrofitting with i) climate-resilient materials and ii) technologies iii) while also taking into consideration the traditional, local or Indigenous building practices that can guide such retrofitting where applicable. New construction that integrates adaptive practices guided by traditional, local, or Indigenous building practices are also included.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: In addition to cultural heritage sites, historic buildings and building stock should be repurposed and reused, where appropriate, retrofitting to protect them from climate change related impacts and hazards. Such retrofitting can be based on (i) new/scientific climate resilient materials or (ii) new or existing technologies or  (iii) guided by traditional, local or Indigenous building practices that already integrate solutions and knowledge responsive to the local geography. Such retrofitting may include new construction guided by traditional, local, or Indigenous building practices.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Metadata for this indicator needs to be developed. Some metadata on traditional, local, and Indigenous building practices exists with UNESCO. Metadata for retrofitting would need to be developed. Several groups including International Union of Architects and others have been working towards this. https://whc.unesco.org/en/culture2030 indicators
Data availability\n(Description): Data is available with Parties at the national, subnational, and local levels including authorities responsible for housing and urban development. Some data is available with UNESCO https://whc.unesco.org/en/  and https://whc.unesco.org/en/indicators2030/. Under the UNFCCC Convention, such data is likely in NAPs or other national documents (NDC, ADCOMs, BTRs, National Communications etc.), other sources include also IPCC, academic literature, grey literature and implementation reports.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (1) Leadership, (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The metadata should define what retrofitting for climate adaptation means and which measures are included. As the indicator is based on a simple number, and the metadata is under development by different organizations, the indicator can be quickly operationalized

Indicator ID: 10(a) Impact, vulnerability and risk assessment: by 2030 all Parties have conducted up-to-date assessments of climate hazards, climate change impacts and exposure to risks and vulnerabilities and have used the outcomes of these assessments to inform their formulation of national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies, and by 2027 all Parties have established multi-hazard early warning systems, climate information services for risk reduction and systematic observation to support improved climate-related data, information and services

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have established multi-hazard early warning systems
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Additional disaggregation by river basins, transboundary risks, ecosystems, etc.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Multi-hazard early warning systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
Total count of Parties that have reported to have established multi-hazard, end-to-end, and people-centered early warning systems disaggregated by sector and GGA targets. 
The indicator will be informed by other indicators in this target, based on the standard four pillars of early warning systems (1) disaster risk knowledge based on the systematic collection of data and disaster risk assessments; (2) detection, monitoring, analysis and forecasting of the hazards and possible consequences; (3) dissemination and communication, by an official source, of authoritative, timely, accurate and actionable warnings and associated information on likelihood and impact; and (4) preparedness at all levels to respond to the warnings received.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Multi-hazard early warning systems are recognized among most cost effective adaptation measures that are highly relevant to protecting populations and economies from quick onset weather and climate-related impacts and has a growing role in managing long-term, slow-onset impacts.

Directly responds to the target statement by capturing measurable evidence towards global coverage and comprehensiveness of multi-hazard early warning systems.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Sendai Framework Monitor Target G, methodology available in Technical Guidance
Data availability\n(Description): Overall data (MHEWS existence) available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015. As of 2025, 119 Parties have reported that they have MHEWS. MHEWS by sectors and GGA targets not readily available.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. Hence, the indicator is ready for GGA reporting purposes.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have accessible, understandable, usable, relevant and up to date climate risk information and comprehensive risk assessment
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Geographic, Climate-related hazards, Any other, Economic sectors, Social categories
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
Additional disaggregation by river basins, transboundary risks, ecosystems, etc.

Further metrics can be considered to assess access to climate information by different sectors and communities.
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Assessments of climate hazards, climate change impacts and exposure to risks and vulnerabilities. 

Multi-hazard early warning systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Total count of Parties that have reported to have climate risk information and comprehensive risk assessments that are accessible, understandable, usable, relevant, and up-to-date. Such risk information generated from comprehensive assessments that address all dimensions of climate-related disaster risk, including hazards, exposure, vulnerability, and capacity, and are based on qualitative and/or quantitative analysis to determine the nature and extent of risk.  include the identification of hazards, review of their technical characteristics (such as location, intensity, frequency, and probability), analysis of physical, social, health, environmental, and economic vulnerabilities, evaluation of coping capacities with respect to likely risk scenarios, and analysis of risk drivers and underlying risk factors. [Adapted from SFM Technical Guidance]
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
To be effective, adaptation measures must be based on or informed by the best available and up-to-date risk information that provides a sound understanding of hazards, exposure, vulnerabilities, and impacts.

'- Directly responds to the target statement by capturing measurable evidence towards "assessments of climate hazards, climate change impacts and exposure to risks and vulnerabilities" (component 1). 

- A quality dimension of headline indicator on MHEWS: Risk information which include risk assessments comprise the foundational Pillar 1 'risk knowledge' of MHEWS.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Sendai Framework Monitor Target G-5, methodology available in Technical Guidance
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have multi-hazard monitoring and impact-based forecasting systems, including monitoring stations
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Multi-hazard early warning systems

Climate information services for risk reduction and systematic observation
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Total count of Parties that have reported to have multi-hazard monitoring and forecasting system for each of the major hazards determined by each Party. Where there is higher quality reporting, this indicator may also capture the quality of such systems. [Adapted from SFM Technical Guidance]
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Observation and forecasting capabilities are foundational to a Party's ability to detect climate-related hazards, to project possible impacts, and issue timely alerts.

A quality dimension of headline indicator on MHEWS: comprises the Pillar 2 of the MHEWS value chain which covers capacities on detection, monitoring, analysis, and forecasting of hazards and possible consequences / impacts
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Sendai Framework Monitor Target G-2, methodology available in Technical Guidance
