Indicator name: Number of people per 100,000 that are covered by early warning information through local governments or through national dissemination mechanisms
Corresponding sub-target / component: Multi-hazard early warning systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Total number of people per 100,000 population that are covered by multi-hazard early warning systems. This indicates the degree of progress being made in commnication, dissemination, and outreach to populations. At the minimum, this is determined by the reporting of the primary media/mode for early warning information through local governments or through national dissemination mechanisms, such as recognized authorities, mass media (radio,TV, internet, website, email, SMS ,social meida, app) and local communication systems (siren, public board, phone). If any of these information modes are available, the population are considered covered. [Adapted from SFM Technical Guidance]
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Tracking dissemination and communication capacities in EWS highlights whether warning information reaches at-risk populations and that they are informed and enabled to take timely action to protect lives and livelihoods.

A quality dimension of headline indicator on MHEWS: comprises the Pillar 3 of the MHEWS value chain which covers capacities on dissemination and communication, by an official source, of authoritative, timel, accurate, and actionable warning and associated information on likelihood and impact.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Sendai Framework Monitor Target G-3, methodology available in Technical Guidance
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Number of National Meteorological and Hydrological Services that have adopted and sustained the use of Common Alerting Protocol
Corresponding sub-target / component: Multi-hazard early warning systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Total count of National Meteorological and Hydrological Services (NMHS) that have formally adopted and are sustaining the operational use of the Common Alerting Protocol (CAP) for the dissemination of hazard alerts and warnings. Adoption implies integration of CAP — an international standard format for all-hazard emergency alerts — into national or sectoral warning systems to enable consistent, secure, and interoperable messaging across multiple communication platforms and agencies. Sustained use indicates that CAP-based alerts are routinely generated, updated, and disseminated for relevant hazards, ensuring timely, accessible, and actionable warning information to stakeholders and the public.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Common Alerting Protocols ensures timely, consistent, and accessible dissemination of early warnings, by standardizing how warnings are issued and shared, enabling faster, clearer, and more coordinated communication among platforms and jurisdications.

A quality dimension of MHEWS: CAP encompasses Pillars 2 and 3 of MHEWS, ensuring standardized message format designed for emergency alerts. It is one of the most important features in the global standards for MHEWS
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Early Warnings for All M&E through WMO Monitoring Systems; methodology set by WMO M&E team
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Percentage of local governments in a country having a plan to act on early warnings
Corresponding sub-target / component: Multi-hazard early warning systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Percentage of local governments within a country that have in place a formally adopted and up-to-date plan to act on early warnings. As in the Sendai Framework definition, a “plan to act on early warnings” may include a preparedness plan, emergency plan, action plan, or any other formal document that specifies who should act, how to act, and the sequence of actions to take when an early warning is issued. AT the minimum, the indicator capture binary accounting of plans in local governments. Where there is better quality reporting, this indicator may also capture quality criteria such as (1) whether public awareness and education is conducted, and (2) whether public awareness and response are tested and evaluated. [Adapted from SFM Technical Guidance]
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Tracking this capability captures how prepared local governments are to act on early warnings, manifested in their local plans. Preparedness is a facet of adaptive behavior.

A quality dimension of headline indicator on MHEWS: comprises the Pillar 4 of the MHEWS value chain that measures preparedness at all levels to respond to the warnings received.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Sendai Framework Monitor Target G-4, methodology available in Technical Guidance
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. Hence, the indicator is ready for GGA reporting purposes. Capacity support for Parties is needed to strengthen reporting.

Indicator name: Percentage of population in a county exposed to or at risk from climate-related disasters protected through pre-emptive evacuation following early warning
Corresponding sub-target / component: Multi-hazard early warning systems
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator quantifies the impact and effectiveness of early warning information in so far as action to temporarily move populations to safer places upon threat of a hazardous event. As evacuation patterns/situations vary greatly by hazardous event, it is suggested that Member States report data by event. [From the SFM Technical Guidance]
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This indicator relates to MHEWS. Pre-emptive evacuation is an observable affirmative behavior to an early warning especially in the case of quick onset weather and climate hazardous events.

From the SFM Technical Guidance: There was discussion among the Sendai expert group that this indicator has two aspects: a) measuring the degree to which the relevant authorities have been successful in avoiding human losses by evacuating populations pre-emptively, and b) measuring the degree to which populations’ lives and assets are negatively affected due
to evacuation.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Sendai Framework Monitor Target G-6, methodology available in Technical Guidance
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015. Parties may not report on this indicator if no evacuations were done in the reporting year.
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have established climate information services for risk reduction and systematic observation to support improved climate-related data, information and services
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Geographic, Climate-related hazards, Any other, Economic sectors
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Further metrics can be considered to assess access to climate information by different sectors and communities.
Corresponding sub-target / component: Climate information services for risk reduction and systematic observation
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Total count of Parties that have established and maintain operational climate information services for risk reduction, supported by systematic observation networks and processes that generate improved climate-related data, information, and services. Such services provide reliable, accessible, and usable climate information tailored to support different productive sectors and various segments of society.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
Adaptation actions in populations and across sectors are reliant on sustained availability of climate information services to ensure these actions and related decisions are grounded on reliable data and timely information.

-Directly responds to the target statement by capturing measurable evidence towards global coverage of "climate information services for risk reduction and systematic observation" (component 4)
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: WMO Monitoring system, methodology set by WMO M&E team
Data availability\n(Description): WMO Monitoring system
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (4) Data & knowledge, (5) Skills & education, (6) Public participation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and data from over 100 Parties are currently available. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have used up-to-date climate risk information and comprehensive risk assessment to inform their formulation of national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Corresponding sub-target / component: Application of assessments to inform their formulation of national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: Total count of Parties that have established and maintain operational climate information services for adaptation and risk reduction, supported by systematic observation networks and processes that generate improved climate-related data, information, and services. Such services provide reliable, accessible, and usable climate information tailored to support different productive sectors and various segments of society to inform adaptation planning.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This captures whether Parties pursue adaptation actions that are evidence-based rather than ad hoc, thereby increasing their effectiveness in promoting adaptation.

-Directly responds to the target statement by capturing measurable evidence towards Parties' "application of (climate risk) assessments to inform their formulation of national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies" (component 2)
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: Some metadata from different sources, mainly reporting instruments to various conventions; respective methods available but no standard approach yet known.
Data availability\n(Description): Not systematically available, but related databases on NAPs and DRR strategies could be a relevant source
Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (5) Skills & education, (4) Data & knowledge
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata and methodological standards need to be developed and Party capacity to monitor and report needs strengthening.

Indicator name: Amount of finance for climate change adaptation for the design, development and operationalisation of climate information services and multi-hazard early warning systems
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
Disaggregated by:
(i) Source of financing; 
(ii) channel (bilateral, multilateral, regional)
(iii) financial instruments (grant, concessional loan, non-concessional loan, equity, guarantee, insurance, other)
Corresponding sub-target / component:
Multi-hazard early warning systems

Climate information services for risk reduction and systematic observation
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The indicator captures the amount of finance from international sources, particularly for the design, development and operationalisation of multi-hazard early warning systems, inclusive of all its pillars and elements, and climate information services. This indicator should use the approach and methodologies agreed under the Standing Committee on Finance
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
MOI indicator that specifically captures support towards 10a components. MHEWS and climate information services require financial, technological and capacity-building support.
Investment in risk assessment, climate information and early warning systems has a multiplier impact as it informs the implementation of other adaptation actions.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Some metadata from different sources.
- SFM system has some limited metadata in connection to reporting to Target F (International support for DRR)
- UNDRR and WMO monitoring systems have technical guidance and programmatic metadata 
- UNFCCC - ETF tools and MPGs; guidance for support reporting. 
- GCF / AF - Results/M&E policy set and portfolio taxonomy available

Some method from different sources but no standard approach yet known
- UNFCCC - voluntarily reporting of support received in BTRs, national communications, etc.
- GCF - IRMF/Results Handbook define measurement for EWS/CI services outputs; can identify “receiving support” by approved projects per country (Party).
Data availability\n(Description):
Various databases from OECD, UNFCCC, UNDRR, WMO, GCF, Adaptation Fund capturing international financing on these elements. 
- UNDRR has available data since 2019 on international support on MHEWS from UN Funds, Programmes, Specialized Agencies and other entities/bodies
- Sendai Framework Monitor has Target F data on official international support to DRR. Does not disaggregate to specifics on MHEWS, climate information services, but captures finance, capacity development, and technology transfer.
- WMO has available data on international support provided to Parties under various programmes like SOFF, CREWS on Pillar 2 of MHEWS and generally on climate information services
- GCF and AF have Public project portfolio and theme pages showing Parties with funded EWS/CI services projects
- UNFCCC - BTRs submitted contain some data; portal(s) give project/finance info but require manual parsing to isolate MHEWS/climate-info support by Party
MOI: \nto measure (1) access, (2) qualit: Adaptation finance including provision, Access, Quality
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata and methodological standards need to be developed and Party capacity to monitor and report needs strengthening.

Indicator ID: 10(b) Planning: by 2030 all Parties have in place country-driven, gender responsive, participatory and fully transparent national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies, covering, as appropriate, ecosystems, sectors, people and vulnerable communities, and have mainstreamed adaptation in all relevant strategies and plans

Indicator name: Number of Parties with adopted national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Thematic targets, Economic sectors, Any other
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by a) inclusion of: (i) national adaptation goals or targets; (ii) cost estimates for the implementation of the proposed activities, including reference to sources of finance (domestic and international, where applicable); (iii) specific measures targeting vulnerable populations; (iv) ecosystem-based adaptation actions or nature-based solutions; (v) measures for sectors and thematic targets; b) presence of national sectoral adapation plans, by sector; c) an inclusive and participatory development process, including Indigenous Peoples where applicable
Corresponding sub-target / component: B1: by 2030 all Parties have in place country-driven, gender-responsive, participatory and fully transparent national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the number of Parties that have an adopted national adaptation plan, policy instruments, planning processes and/or strategies as part of their national policy landscape. It reflects the extent to which countries are institutionalizing adaptation planning processes in line with target 10b. The disaggregation gathers (a) information about particular features of those plans and policy instruments, (b) whether seperate national sectoral adaptation plans exist (e.g. a Health National Adaptation Plan), and (c) information about the inclusivity of their planning process
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Captures an element of target 10b pertaining to adaptation plans, policy instruments and processes being in place by 2030. The disaggregation captures essential features of the adaptation planning instrument(s) as well as the inclusivity of their development process. The disaggregation is important to track the quality of national adaptation planning.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: From the Adaptation Gap Report (planning chapter) and its Annex. Needs modifications to capture the disaggregation aspects.
Data availability\n(Description):
From the Adaptation Gap Report (planning chapter) and its Annex and from the UNFCCC secretariat's annual NAP progress report. Also through the online platforms NAP Central (hosted by the UNFCCC secretariat) and NAP Trends (hosted by the NAP Global Network), as well as from Party submissions and reporting to the UNFCCC secretariat including via BTRs, Adaptation Communications and National Communications, and in national documents such as NAPs or equivalent policy instruments.  

WHO provides guidance and collects data from countries of their implementation of Health NAPs
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Requires the development of a methodology for the indicator and its disaggregation. The methodology used by the planning chapter of the Adaptation Gap Report can be used as a basis (it is described in the Annex of each year's report). “Adopted” can be defined as a formally approved and publicly available national document. The presence of documents can be verifiedy via NAP Central, the Adaptation Gap Report, NAP Trends, national government websites and official gazettes, regional websites like the European "Climate Adapt" platform, or global climate policy databases like "Climate change laws of the world".

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have adopted national legislation or other legislative frameworks on adaptation
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by a) type of instrument (e.g. law, executive decree, policy, strategy); b) sectoral coverage, and; c) level of enforcement (e.g. mandatory vs. voluntary)
Corresponding sub-target / component: B1: by 2030 all Parties have in place country-driven, gender-responsive, participatory and fully transparent national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the number of Parties that have enacted national laws dedicated to climate adaptation. It demonstrates the degree to which adaptation is being embedded in legally binding frameworks, providing a foundation for coordinated and enforceable action.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Important enabler for national adaptation actions and providing a higher level of ambition than relying only on the adoption of adaptation plans and other policy instruments. Legislation signals political committment and is more enforcable. It can also provide more stability across changes in government.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The methodology of the planning chapter of the Adaptation Gap Report (Annex of the 2023 edition) can be used as a starting point but needs modifications to capture the disaggregation aspects.
Data availability\n(Description): Adaptation Gap Report's planning chapter (2023) and the Climate Change Laws of the World database (https://climate-laws.org/), the website of planning, environment and justice ministries or official gazettes.
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Requires the development of a methodology for the indicator and its disaggregation. The methodology used by the planning chapter of the Adaptation Gap Report can be used as a basis (it is described in the Annex of each year's report; the 2023 edition featured adaptation laws for the first time).

Indicator name: Number of Parties receiving or mobilizing international support for formulation of National Adaptation Plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies, including for capacity development
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by a) sector (for cases where plans or policy instruments are sector-specific)
Corresponding sub-target / component: B1: by 2030 all Parties have in place country-driven, gender-responsive, participatory and fully transparent national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the number of Parties that are accessing or mobilizing international finance and technical support for the development of planning processes. It highlights the role of external resources in strengthening national adaptation planning.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Finance and capacity development indicator that is directly connected to the development of adaptation planning instruments.
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: UNFCCC secretariat (LDC Expert Group support unit) but needs modifications to capture the disaggregation aspects.
Data availability\n(Description): Since 2015, the LDC Expert Group has been producing an annual progress report on the process to formulate and implement NAPs which includes a section on support recieved. Relevant information may also be provided in NAPs, BTRs, Adaptation Communications, and National Communications. Climate budget tagging could provide an additional source of information, where available.
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The process used by the LDC Expert Group for the annual NAP progess report could be used as basis for a spelled-out metadata. Modifications would need to be elaborated for the different disaggregation aspects. OECD-DAC and fund portals could be used for verification.

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have in place gender-responsive adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by the following features: (a) gender experts were formally involved in the development of the plans; (b) plans include gender-specific targets/goals or outcomes; (c) Parties have mechanisms to track gender-specific financial allocations for the implementation of the adaptation plans; (d) plans or their MEL system include gender-specific indicators; and (e) Parties report progress on the implementation of the gender-specific targets/goals or outcomes of their adaptation plans and include gender disaggregated data for any relevant indicators
Corresponding sub-target / component: B1: by 2030 all Parties have in place country-driven, gender-responsive, participatory and fully transparent national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the number of Parties that have adopted adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies with explicit gender-responsive provisions. The disaggregation provides further details about the gender-responsiveness.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator addresses the gender-responsive provision of the target. It measures the gender responsiveness of national adaptation planning.
Data availability\n(Description): Several online portals on NAPs include relevant information on gender-responsiveness of NAPs including the online platforms NAP Central (hosted by the UNFCCC secretariat) and NAP Trends (hosted by the NAP Global Network). The annual NAP progress reort of the UNFCCC secretariat also includes information in gender considerations in NAPs.
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Requires the development of metadata especially for the disaggregation aspects

Indicator name: Proportion of National Adaptation Plans, policy instruments, and planning processes that have been informed by traditional knowledge, knowledge of Indigenous Peoples, and local knowledge systems
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by a) type of knowledge system (Indigenous, traditional, community-based)
Corresponding sub-target / component: B1: by 2030 all Parties have in place country-driven, gender-responsive, participatory and fully transparent national adaptation plans, policy instruments, and planning processes and/or strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the share of Parties where Indigenous Peoples, and local communities are actively involved in the development of adaptation plans, and where Indigenous, traditional, and local ways of knowing have informed the creation of NAPs, policy instruments, and planning processes. It reflects the commitment to participatory and inclusive approaches in adaptation planning, and mutlipe evidence approaches.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Addresses the sub-target of participatory adaptation plans
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: A methodology/metadata for the engagement of Indigenous Peoples and local communities and for them having informed the plans and policies would need to be developed. Cross-check with an IPLC advisory review.

Indicator name: Proportion of local governments that have integrated climate change adaptation into policies, legal frameworks, budgets, plans and processes
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by type of instrument (plan, policy, strategy, legal framework, budget)
Corresponding sub-target / component: B2: Parties have mainstreamed adaptation in all relevant strategies and plans;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks how many local governments have embedded adaptation priorities in local planning frameworks.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Captures mainstreaming of adaptation at the local government level and therefore responds to the mainstreaminf component of target 10b.
Units: % of local authorities; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: A methodology/metadata needs to be developed including a) a clear definition of "local authorities", b) ways to determine the total number of relevant local authorities, c) an operational definition of "integrated", d) for disaggregation including by authority type

Indicator name: Number of Parties with a legal requirement for public investments to take into account climate risks including in planning, implementation and maintenance
Corresponding sub-target / component: B2: Parties have mainstreamed adaptation in all relevant strategies and plans;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks whether Parties have adopted legal requirements for public investments to to into account climate risks.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Addresses an important adaptation enabler, captures the mainstreaming aspect of target 10b. Legal requirements for public investments can increase the resilience of investments against climate hazards and reduce costs in the future,
Data availability\n(Description): Information may be available from international reporting e.g. BTRs, Adaptation Communications, or National Communications or from national documents including NAPs and from government websites
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: A methodology/metadata needs to be developed including a definition of "legal requirement"

Indicator name: Number of Parties that have systems in place for considering climate risks in public procurement
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by a) sector (for cases where the regulation is specific to particular sectors or themes); b) procurement scope; and c) geographic scope that the regulation refers to (national, sub-national, etc.)
Corresponding sub-target / component: B2: Parties have mainstreamed adaptation in all relevant strategies and plans;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator tracks the existence of systems that ensure that public spending accounts for climate risks and therefore requires or incentivizes adaptation.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Addresses the mainstreaming aspect of target 10b. Captures an important enabler, and demonstrates leadership from the public sector.
Data availability\n(Description): Information may be available from international reporting e.g. BTRs, Adaptation Communications, or National Communications or from national documents including NAPs and from government websites. Standard tender clauses/specs, evaluation criteria, e-procurement data, and default contract KPIs could indicate the presence of such systems
Units: Number of Parties; different units for disaggregation
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: A methodology/metadata needs to be developed

Indicator name: Number of Parties where national budgets reflect adaptation allocations across sectors and ministries and where adaptation is integrated into national and sectoral plans (including development plans and budgets where applicable)
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by a) sector; b) timeframe (e.g. budget year, plan cycle)
Corresponding sub-target / component: B2: Parties have mainstreamed adaptation in all relevant strategies and plans;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the degree to which national budgets integrate and prioritize adaptation actions identified in planning frameworks, as well as integration of adaptation into other relevant national and sectoral plans.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Incoporation of adaptation into budgets as well as into other planning instruments at various levels is an important way of mainstreaming adaptation.
Data availability\n(Description): Information may be available from international reporting e.g. BTRs, Adaptation Communications, or National Communications or from national documents including NAPs and from national budget information.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Desk review with a template mapping sector allocations.  Evidence includes climate budget tagging or equivalent tagging and sectoral allocation tables.  Count Parties with (i) tagging in plans and (ii) sectoral allocation tables.

Indicator name: Proportion of government budget allocated to climate adaptation and resilience
Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Economic sectors, Any other, Geographic, Thematic targets
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregation by timeframe and financing source
Corresponding sub-target / component: B2: Parties have mainstreamed adaptation in all relevant strategies and plans;
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the share of government expenditure directed to adaptation priorities, reflecting financial commitment to adaptation.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Addresses the mainstreaming aspect of target 10b and is an important finance indicator. Demonstrates domestic financial commitment to adaptation through budget mainstreaming and provides a data point for assessing national effort and potential finance shortfalls.
Data availability\n(Description): Collected by some Parties including through climate budget tagging
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: A methodology/metadata needs to be developed. What counts as adaptation and resilience could be either standardised or remain self-determined by every country e.g. based on national climate budget tagging.
Remarks: The reason for placing this indicator with 10b is its role for mainstreaming

Indicator ID: 10(c) Implementation: by 2030 all Parties have progressed in implementing their national adaptation plans, policies and strategies and, as a result, have reduced the social and economic impacts of the key climate hazards identified in the assessments referred to in paragraph 10(a) above

Indicator name: Degree of implementation of national adaptation plans, policies and strategies
Corresponding sub-target / component: c.1 - by 2030 all Parties have progressed in implementing their national adaptation plans, policies and strategies
Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the degree to which national adaptation plans, including the measurable targets/goals and adaptation measures/actions listed in the national adaptation plans, policies and strategies are implemented. It is proposed to measure two parts: a) the share of measurable targets/goals on track of being acheived; b) proportion of adaptation actions at different levels of implementation (e.g. not started, under implementation, completed)
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Measures a central component of target 10c and measures whether the adaptation plans under target 10b are being implemented
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The implementation chapter of the Adaptation Gap Report 2024 contains an analysis of NAP progress reports that can inform the development of metadata for this indicator. At the regional level, the European Union compiles regular progress reports that may also be relevant to inform the development of metadata
Data availability\n(Description): Websites like NAP Trends count the number of adaptation actions per NAP (currently only disclosed as average and only for developing countries). Implementation of national adaptation plans in the EU is reported under the GovReg regulations and available data sets in the Climate-ADAPT portal (https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en).  NAP progress reports and NAP evaluations as well as country reporting to the UNFCCC secretariat (e.g. via BTRs) willl be the primary data source for this indicator.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Requires developing a standardised way to determine the number of actions in NAPs. Information about the level of implementation is typically provided in NAP implementation reports (see Leiter, 2021 and Adaptation Gap Report 2024, chapter 3). More challenging is to develop a standardised way of determining whether measurable targets are on track.
Remarks: Based on the experiences of chapter 3 of the Adaptation Gap Report 2024, part b) of the indicator description will be easier to measure in the short term. External evaluations of NAP implementation could supplement the indicator regarding the quality of the implementation.

Indicator name: Number of deaths and missing persons associated with climate-related hazards, per 100,000 population
Corresponding sub-target / component: c.2 - and, as a result, have reduced the social and economic impacts of key climate hazards
Description of the indicator \n(with def: The indicator is modified from Sendai Framework Target A, and SDG targets 1.5, 11.5 and 13.1 and measures progress in decline in social impacts of climate hazards.  While the indicator captures the absolute number, the analysis is recommended to be done over years to capture change over time to understand and track adaptation effectiveness.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This indicator captures loss of life and missing persons from climate-related disasters, serving as a direct measure of human and social impact. 
While providing the data on reduced social impact of climate hazards under this target (10c), the indicator also provides data for the Target 9c, especially the component "reducing climate-related mortality."

The climate related impact on mortality and human population and has its universality across all countries, and time series of this indicator reflect the adaptation capacity and resilience of the society. 
Change of the ratio over time tracks the adaptation effectiveness against climate-related disasters when analyzed against indicators capturing adaptation actions.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment, 9f Poverty & livelihoods
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
This indicator is modified from a Sendai Framework target and its metadata is readily available at the Technical Guidance of Sendai Framework.

www.undrr.org/quick/11641
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Methodology, data standards and reported data are currently available. More support is needed to develop metadata for disaggregation and its reporting by Parties.

Indicator name: Number of people who experienced direct social and economic impacts associated with climate-related hazards per 100,000 people
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info:
Disaggregated by (a) Injured or ill people, (b) People with damaged dwellings, (c) People with destroyed dwellings, (d) People whose livelihoods were disrupted or destroyed
(e) People experiencing mental/physical health ailments as a result; (f) People experiencing barriers to access medical care or hygiene products; (g) People experiencing temporary or permanent displacement; (h) People who decreased food intake as a result; (i) People experiencing drops in agricultural yield; (j) People experiencing job losses; (k) People seeing increases in their unpaid care or domestic work; (l) People experiencing increases in time spent on the production of environmental goods
Corresponding sub-target / component: c.2 - and, as a result, have reduced the social and economic impacts of key climate hazards
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
The first part of the indicator is modified from Sendai Framework Target B, and SDG targets 1.5, 11.5 and 13.1. The specific elements of disaggregation provide information on other targets, e.g. (a) Number of injured or ill people - provides information for Target 9c on health, (b) Number of people with damaged dwellings and (c) Number of people with destroyed dwellings - provide information for Target 9e on IHS, (d) Number of people whose livelihoods were disrupted or destroyed - provides information for Target 9f on poverty and livelihoods.

The second part of the indicator is a Gender-Environment Indicator managed by UN Women and components of it are part of the Global Set of Climate Change Statistics and Indicators managed by UNSD. All sub-categories (from A to L) can be disaggregated by climate-related hazard.
This indicator also contributes to Target 9c (climate-related injured and ill people), 9e (damaged and destroyed dwellings), and 9f (livelihoods lost due to climate-related hazards). 

While the indicator captures the absolute number, the analysis is recommended to be done over years to capture change over time to understand and track adaptation effectiveness.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This indicator measures the scale of population directly affected by climate-related hazards, capturing both social and economic consequences, providing information on the adaptation capacity of the society. This is a key metric for tracking progress toward reducing climate-related impacts. The climate impact on human population has its universality across all countries, applies to different climate events, and time series of the indicator reflect increased adaptation capacity and resilience. 
Change of the ratio over time tracks the adaptation effectiveness against climate-related disasters when analyzed against indicators capturing adaptation actions.
Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage, 10a MHEWS & risk assessment
Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
The first part of this indicator is modified from a Sendai Framework target and its metadata is readily available at the Technical Guidance of Sendai Framework.
www.undrr.org/quick/11641

For the second part, metadata, data collection tools (for national surveys) and syntax for calculation of this indicator is also available at data.unwomen.org
Data availability\n(Description): Data available since start of voluntary reporting to Sendai Framework Monitoring in 2015. Data also available from national Gender and Environment surveys.
Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Greater levels of disaggregation for the indicator will require additioanl work to develop the metadata and capacity support to Parties to systematically collect the data and report.

Indicator name: Direct economic loss associated with climate-related hazards as a proportion of gross domestic product
Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Additional disaggregation by economic losses resulting from climate-related hazards can be computed for the thematic targets
Corresponding sub-target / component: c.2 - and, as a result, have reduced the social and economic impacts of key climate hazards
Description of the indicator \n(with def:
The indicator is modified from Sendai Framework Target C, and SDG targets 11.5.
This indicator also contributes to Targets 9b (agricultural losses), 9e (infrastructure and housing sector losses), 9f (losses in productive assets in economic sectors) and 9g (cultural heritage losses).

While the indicator captures the absolute number, the analysis is recommended to be done over years to capture change over time to understand and track adaptation effectiveness.
Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta:
This indicator measures the economic impact of climate-related disasters relative to national income, revealing the scale of financial vulnerability to climate risks. 
Change of the ratio over time tracks the adaptation effectiveness against climate-related disasters when analyzed against indicators capturing adaptation actions.

rawData.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This is an aspect of availability of finance. sectorName: [Option 1] Amount of private sector finance directed towards climate adaptation annually including private finance mobilized through public interventions

rawData.Indicator name: [Option 1] Amount of private sector finance directed towards climate adaptation annually including private finance mobilized through public interventions
rawData.Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Thematic targets, Economic sectors, Any other
rawData.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by (i) domestic and international private finance, (ii) type of private finance institutions, (iii) type of financial instrument, (iv) sectors and thematic targets, (v) adaptation technology development and capacity building components, (vi) amount invested by private sector in developing and developed countries;
rawData.Corresponding sub-target / component: c1 - Parties have progressed in implementing their national adaptation plans, policies and strategies
rawData.Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator seeks to track the annual amount of finance from all types of private finance that is specifically directed towards adaptation investments, including the amount mobilised through public intervention such as blended finance arrangements.
rawData.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: By complementing the indicator on international public finance, this indicator plays a crucial role in quantifying the total volume of private sector finance directed towards climate adaptation efforts and in elucidating the overall flow—and gaps—of adaptation finance. Such quantification is vital for effectively scaling the investments needed to address climate risks. Despite existing methodological challenges, improved tracking can offer detailed insights into the amounts, geographical distribution, thematic focus, and categories of private finance supporting adaptation. This enhanced transparency fosters greater accountability in global climate finance flows and supports more informed decision-making by policymakers and stakeholders. Moreover, tracking reveals the diverse ways in which private sector finance can contribute to climate adaptation and helps identify promising opportunities to leverage increased private investment, thereby accelerating progress toward resilient and sustainable climate solutions.
rawData.Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage
rawData.Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
There are existing methodologies that seek to track private adaptation finance flow, such as the Climate Policy Initiative's methodology "Tracking and Mobilizing Private Sector Climate Adaptation Finance". With regards to the specific component on private finance mobilized through public interventions, OECD's 2025 report "Tracking private finance mobilisation", which covers adaptation, also provides a general reference. 

However, existing methodologies are not able to capture all types of private sector sources and would need refinement to fit into the GGA context. The methodology may require regular review and update, if needed, to stay up to date with evolving methodolgies in classifying adaptation investments and
rawData.Data availability\n(Description): There are existing global tracking data available from organisations such as he Climate Policy Initiatives. However, data availability at national level would be further investigated.
rawData.Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Relevant methodology and data are partially available at the global level, however further refinement of existing methodologies and/or development of a methodology that fits under the GGA context is still needed, especially in terms of tracking finance flow under different financing arrangements and classifying/qualifying adaptation investments. Initial testing phase could be done through collaboration with relevant organisations that are focusing on tracking global private adaptation finance.
rawData.Remarks: There should be effort to define what will be defined as private sector finance.

This may be addressed by the linkage with thematic targets which will outline a broad scope of adaptation implementation.

sectorName: [Option 1] Level of implementation of adaptation technology needs identified by developing countries, including needs expressed in Technology Needs Assessments (TNAs), NAPs, NDCs and other equivalent policy instruments, including their development and transfer from developed to developing countries

rawData.Indicator name: [Option 1] Level of implementation of adaptation technology needs identified by developing countries, including needs expressed in Technology Needs Assessments (TNAs), NAPs, NDCs and other equivalent policy instruments, including their development and transfer from developed to developing countries
rawData.Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Thematic targets, Economic sectors, Geographic, Any other
rawData.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by (i) level of implementation by sector and thematic targets; (ii) level of technology development, (iii) channel of technology transfer, (iv) direction of transfer (developed to developing, developing to developing); (v) by region in which the development is taking place (developing or developed country Parties)
rawData.Corresponding sub-target / component: c1 - Parties have progressed in implementing their national adaptation plans, policies and strategies
rawData.Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator measures the extent to which adaptation technology needs by developing country Parties are being implemented, including development and transfer where appropriate. It is proposed to be is measured through quantitative and qualitative information on: 
(i) strategies implemented to support technology development and transfer; 
(ii) support, including financial and capacity building provided at different stages of the technology cycle; and 
(iii) support for the development and enhancement of existing capacities and adaptation technologies of developing country Parties
rawData.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Adaptation technology is crucial for the implementation of adaptation by developing countries. Thus, the implementation of adaptation technology needs expressed by developing countries is important. This indicator acknowledges the importance of technology development and transfer through various paths including from developed to developing, developing to developing and developing to developed. However, support for the development of technology recognises the important role developed Parties play.

Data for implementation this indicator could come from Climate Technology Initiative (TEC) and the Climate Technology Centre and Network (CTCN), UNTAD, OECD, SDG, UN Technology Bank, BTRs, AdCooms

Data on adaptation technology needs will come from national documents mainly the TNAs, NDCs, NAPs, and relevant policy documents
rawData.Units: Qualitative description of the levels of implementation, development, and transfer
rawData.Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata should clearly define the different levels of implementation by sector and theme so that information on this indicator can show progress on sectors or themes where technology implementation, development and transfer is performing better or where there is little progress on these aspects. Metadata should also clearly define the different levels of technology development, and possible channels of technology transfer.

Data for implementation this indicator could come from Climate Technology Initiative (TEC) and the Climate Technology Centre and Network (CTCN), UNTAD, OECD, SDG, UN Technology Bank, BTRs, AdCooms

rawData.Units: Qualitative description of the levels of implementation, development, and transfer
rawData.Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Metadata should clearly define the different levels of implementation by sector and theme so that information on this indicator can show progress on sectors or themes where technology implementation, development and transfer is performing better or where there is little progress on these aspects. Metadata should also clearly define the different levels of technology development, and possible channels of technology transfer.

indicators.Indicator name: Number of Parties with institutional arrangements for the provision of regular training on climate change adaptation at the national and local level for governments and non-government organisations including community-based organisations
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: c1 - Parties have progressed in implementing their national adaptation plans, policies and strategies
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def: Institutional arrangements could include designated national training institutes/universities/other private sector providers/Technical and Vocational Institutions with curricula that cover climate change adaptation. "Regular" refers to established courses rather than one-off training exercises.
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: The indicator is oriented towards longer-term capacity building at the insitutional level, as opposed to short-term project based training.  Not currently tracked in a systematic way, this indicator is relevant to all countries. Sustained capacity building on adaptation action over a longer term is required in a whole of government and whole of society approach, in particular when including and/or targeting vulnerable groups.

indicators.Indicator name: Extent of capacity-building interventions enhancing adaptive capacity of vulnerable communities/people
indicators.Disaggregation levels \n(as relevant & f: Thematic targets, Economic sectors, Social categories, Any other
indicators.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Disaggregated by (i) sector and thematic target, (ii) social categories such as sex, age, people with disabilities, migrants and displaced people, Indigenous Peoples, local communities
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: c1 - Parties have progressed in implementing their national adaptation plans, policies and strategies
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def:
This indicator measures the extent to which capacity building interventions have increased the adaptive capacity of vulnerable people/communities to climate change impacts and hazards. Measured through:
 (a) Qualitative information on (i) nature of strategies employed for capacity building of the vulnerable people, (ii) existence of a national and subnational policy(ies) that promote the integration of climate change adaptation in school curriculum, including professional training institutes and colleges, (iii) level of engagement of vulnerable people in capacity building interventions and (iv) level of the measures implemented to address the capacity building needs, priorities, and gaps identified in CNAs; and
(b) Quantitative data on (i) proportion of vulnerable people reached by capacity building interventions, (ii) proportion of vulnerable people with improved skills to adapt including diversifying livelihoods away from climate sensitive sectors, (iii) number of adaptation-related research and development programs integrating indigenous and traditional knowledge in various levels of education (from primary, secondary, high school and post-school such as vocational training colleges and universities).
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Capacity building to implement adaptation measures and actions is a critical component for enhancing adaptive capacity, one of the three pillars of GGA.
indicators.Other target(s) \nit is relevant for: 9a Water & sanitation, 9b Food & agricultural, 9c Health, 9d Ecosystems & biodiversity, 9e Infrastructure & human settlements, 9f Poverty & livelihoods, 9g Cultural heritage
indicators.Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip:
Metadata on capacity building is partially available from UNICEF, SDG:

https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-13-03-01.pdf
indicators.Data availability\n(Description): Parties are providing the data in the BTRs, AdComms. Data can also come from existing frameworks such as the SDG, Sendai. Data can come from relevant UN agencies, UN Cimate Funds such as the GCF, AF, LDCF, GEF.
indicators.Units: This will be an index with information presented both in qualitative and quantitative form
indicators.Operationalisation \nof the indicator: The metadata of the indicator should consist of series of sub-questions that parties will complete in different forms when reporting progress. The metadata to define how terms such as level for each sub-item in the indicator are considered.
indicators.Remarks: This is an index with both qualitative and quantitative information collected. This is because capacity building issues are complex to be captured in absolute numbers. The indicator follows the structure that capacity building information should be reported by Parties in the BTRs.

indicators.Indicator ID: 10(d) Monitoring, evaluation and learning: by 2030 all Parties have designed, established and operationalized a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts and have built the required institutional capacity to fully implement the system

indicators.Indicator name: Number of Parties that have designed a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: (i) stage of the development process; (ii) inclusion of a stakeholder mechanism ensuring an inclusive and participatory development process
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: D1: Designed, established and operationalised a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator measures the development of a MEL system for national adaptation efforts. The process of designing the MEL system takes time and resources, similar to the development of a NAP. Hence, this indicator is disaggregated by the different design stages of a national MEL system (commitment, early stage and advanced stage of development). The disaggregation of this indicator tracks whether the process of designing the MEL system has been inclusive, especially whether vulnerable groups, local communities, Indigenous Peoples, have been particiating.
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: A MEL system is part of insitutional arrangements for adaptation. The indicator is globally relevant since the function of tracking progress is applicable to all contexts. The specifics of each MEL system for national adaptation efforts need to be specific to national circumstances.
indicators.Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: A global stocktake of NAP M&E systems in 2021 identified common stages of the development and operationalisation in over 50 countries (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1462901121002379). Its findings could inform the developmente of metadata.
indicators.Data availability\n(Description): The annual NAP progress report of the LDC Expet Group lists the number of countries engaged in element D of the NAP process. UNEP's Adaptation Gap Report also provides relevant data in its planning chapter and in the Annex. International reporting to the UNFCCC secretariat including via BTRs, Adaptation Comunications, and National Communications, or national documents like NAPs  can include this information.
indicators.Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Based on existing sources (see column on metadata availability), the metadata needs to be complated, including for the disaggregation aspects.

indicators.Indicator name: Number of Parties that have operationalised a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: By stages of the establishment of the MEL system
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: D1: Designed, established and operationalized a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def: Quantitative indicator to monitor the operational status of the MEL system, once it has been designed and established. This includes active data collection and reporting, and can also include evaluations and learning mechanisms to inform policy or programmatic adjustments. The indicator measures operationalisation, existence of evaluation functions and existence of learning functions
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator assesses the operationalisation level of the MEL system, responding to the target together with indicator 10d01. It is globally relevant, as the operationalisation of a MEL system is applicable to all Parties.
indicators.Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: A global stocktake of NAP M&E systems in 2021 identified common stages of the development and operationalisation in over 50 countries (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1462901121002379). Its findings could inform the developmente of metadata.

UNEP's Adaptation Gap Report also provides relevant data in its planning chapter and in the Annex. International reporting to the UNFCCC secretariat including via BTRs, Adaptation Comunications, and National Communications, or national documents like NAPs can include this information.
indicators.Operationalisation \nof the indicator: Based on existing sources (see column on metadata availability), the metadata needs to be complated, including for the disaggregation aspects.

indicators.Indicator name: Number of Parties that periodically publish adequately detailed MEL findings of the implementation of their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: (a) Type of publication (national progress or implementation report, international reporting, publication of an evaluation); (b) reporting frequency; c) coverage of thematic targets in MEL findings
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: D1: Designed, established and operationalized a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def: Quantitative indicator to capture the transparency of the MEL process through the dissemination and communication of MEL findings. Reporting can be done via a standalone national adaptation (NAP) progress or implementation report or via international reporting such as via a BTR, Adaptation Communication or a National Communication
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Accessible dissemination of the MEL findings is crucial to ensure transparency and accountability, as well as to enable application of the findings for learning. The indicator is globally relevant since progress tracking is applicable to all countries
indicators.Metadata availability\n(Source & Descrip: The implementation chapter of the Adaptation Gap Report reviewed available NAP progress report. The Annex of the 2024 report includes the methodology. A global stocktake of NAP M&E systems undertaken in 2021 also includes a method to systematically gather these reports (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1462901121002379).

UNEP's Adaptation Gap Report also provides relevant data in its planning chapter and in the Annex. International reporting to the UNFCCC secretariat including via BTRs, Adaptation Comunications, and National Communications, or national documents like NAPs can include this information.

indicators.Indicator name: Level of integration of MEL system findings into relevant plans, policies, processes, legal frameworks, and budgets
indicators.Disaggregation levels \n(additional info: Thematic targets (to determine whether the integration occurs into plans or policies that refer to a particular thematic target, and for which ones)
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: D1: Designed, established and operationalized a system for monitoring, evaluation and learning for their national adaptation efforts
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def: This indicator aims to capture the extent to which the findings from the MEL systems are integrated into national/sectoral policies as well as other relevant processes. It could be measured on a scale that accounts for the responsiveness of decision processes to MEL findings, e.g. from fully integrated (MEL findings are routinely acted upon), to partly integrated (processes exist to channel MEL findings into planning, but uptake is inconsistent), to not integrated (MEL findings are acknowledged but not systematically used).
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: This indicator is directly about adaptation since it tracks whether MEL findings on the implementation of national adaptation efforts are being acted upon and informing relevant decision processes. Hence, it investigates the important linkages between MEL findings and the subsequent planning process. It is part of adaptation governance, as the purpose of a MEL system is not just to collect data, but to actively inform planning and decision making. It is globally relevant since tracking progress of national adaptation efforts applicable to all Parties.
indicators.Data availability\n(Description): Releant information may be included in international reporting to the UNFCCC secretariat including via BTRs, Adaptation Comunications, and National Communications, or in national documents
indicators.Other enabling factors\n(for which the i: (2) Institutional arrangements, (3) Policies, (7) Strengthened & inclusive governance

indicators.Indicator name: Number of Parties with sufficient institutional capacity, including adequate financial resources, to fully operate the national adaptation MEL system
indicators.Corresponding sub-target / component: D2: have built the required institutional capacity to fully implement the system
indicators.Description of the indicator \n(with def: This is a qualitative indicator to assess the institutional capacity, including adequate financial resources, of Parties to operate the MEL system. It assesses institutional readiness, and in turn identifies capacity-building needs. The different levels could account for: institutional mandates, capacity building efforts, mechanisms for interagency coordination, and availability and type of human resources, technical infrastructure and budgetary resources
indicators.Rationale of the indicator\n(with adapta: Adequate capacities, including finanical resources, to operationalize the MEL system, are essential to ensuring its long-term sustainability, operational effectiveness, and quality assurance.
indicators.Data availability\n(Description): The data collection requires a process of stock taking  for the institutional arrangement for adaptation managment. This involves identifying, documenting, and assessing the roles, mandates, coordination mechanisms, and operational capacities of institutions currently engaged in climate adaptation efforts. The outcomes could then be analyzed and catogerized for example, by function (policy, implementation, monitoring), scale (national, subnational, local), or thematic relevance (water, agriculture, health). to respond to this reporting requirment
